https destination-port deny all

If the HTTPS proxy is not necessary to an installation, then the command "https destination-port allow 443" can be excluded from the above workaround.

Title: Cisco Content Service Switch (CSS) 11000 Can Be Reset By Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Cisco's Content Service Switch (CSS) 11000 series switches.  A remote user can cause the device to reset.
The bug is reportedly due to improper handling of HTTP POST requests submitted to the web management interface.  A remote user can cause the device to reset (soft reset) using two different exploit methods.

The web server management port (listening on TCP/8081) apparently cannot process XML data.  A remote user can send XML data over http to cause a soft reset.

A remote user can send an HTTPS post request to the web server management port to cause the device to reset.  This apparently does not require the user to be authenticated to the device.

Cisco reports that the CSS 11000 series (CSS 11050, CSS 11150, and CSS 11800) hardware platforms running Cisco WebNS Software are affected.  The 11000 series switches with the following WebNS versions are vulnerable:

04.01.053s and earlier 
05.00.038s and earlier 
05.01.012s and earlier 
05.02.005s and earlier 

The 11500 Series switches with following WebNS version is vulnerable:

05.10.0.01
Impact': A remote user can cause the device to reset.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix:

Cisco WebNS Software

Version Affected, Fixed Regular Release (available now).

4.01, 5.00.045 
5.0, 5.00.045 
5.01, 5.03 
5.02, 5.03 
5.10, TBD 

Cisco notes that the fix carries forward into all later versions.

Title: Cisco IOS Systems Contain Network Time Daemon (NTP) Buffer Overflow That May Allow a Remote User to Crash the Device
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Cisco IOS in the network time protocol (NTP) daemon.  A remote user may be able to cause the IOS device to crash.
The vulnerability reportedly exists in the NTP daemon query processing functionality.  A remote user can send a specially crafted NTP query packet to trigger a buffer overflow in the NTP daemon.  Although it may be possible to cause arbitrary code to be executed on some platforms, Cisco does not believe that code can be executed on Cisco IOS platforms.

Cisco reports that the following products are vulnerable:

All releases of Cisco IOS software 
Media Gateway Controller (MGC) and related products 
BTS 10200 
Cisco IP Manager 

[Editor's note:  It appears that the underlying vulnerability in the NTP daemon code is the same as was reported for generic ntpd implementations way back in April 2001.]
Impact': A remote user may be able to cause the system to crash.  Note that Cisco has not been able to reproduce the crash, but a user has reported that it is possible and Cisco indicates that it may indeed be possible.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  To determine the appropriate fix, please refer to the table contained in the Cisco advisory, available at:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/ntp-pub.shtml

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: Nortel CVX-1800 Multi-service Access Switch Discloses Administrative Account Names and Passwords to Remote Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in Nortel's CVX-1800 mulit-service access switch (modem bank).  In the default configuration, a remote user can obtain certain account names and passwords from the system.
It is reported that a remote user can query the device via SNMP to obtain the user names and passwords for all locally configured telnet accounts.  These are apparently the accounts used to configure the CVX itself and not the user names and passwords of dial-up users serviced by the device. 

The following 'snmpwalk' command can reportedly be used:

snmpwalk CVX-IP-ADD-RESS public .1

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can obtain user account names and passwords for locally configured telnet accounts.
Solution:
The vendor issued a fix.  It is reported that Product Bulletin No. DB022002-1, Issue 3 advises that a software code update (patch) has been issued for Version 3.6.3P25, and recommends an upgrade from 3.6.3P24 to that version. The bulletin also reportedly gives recommended mitigating practices in case an immediate upgrade is not possible.

Nortel has provided information about the CERT Advisory-related SNMP vulnerabilities and their status for all Nortel Networks at the following URL:

http://www.nortelnetworks.com/corporate/technology/snpmv1.html

  To obtain Product Bulletin No. DB022002-1, Issue 3, you can reportedly contact Nortel Networks Global Technical Support:

North America: 1-800-4-NORTEL, or (1-800-466-7835)

Europe, Middle East & Africa: 00800 8008 9009, or +44 (0) 870 907 9009

Contacts for other regions are available at:

http://www.nortelnetworks.com/help/contact/global

According to the vendor, this vulnerability was fixed as part of a patch for the recently reported SNMP vulnerabilities (documented in CERT Advisory CA-2002-03).

Title: Nortel CVX-1800 Multi-service Access Switch Discloses Administrative Account Names and Passwords to Remote Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in Nortel's CVX-1800 mulit-service access switch (modem bank).  In the default configuration, a remote user can obtain certain account names and passwords from the system.
It is reported that a remote user can query the device via SNMP to obtain the user names and passwords for all locally configured telnet accounts.  These are apparently the accounts used to configure the CVX itself and not the user names and passwords of dial-up users serviced by the device. 

The following 'snmpwalk' command can reportedly be used:

snmpwalk CVX-IP-ADD-RESS public .1

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can obtain user account names and passwords for locally configured telnet accounts.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report has provided the following recommendation:

"Change your SNMP community string to something other than it's default value of public."

Title: Cisco Aironet Wireless Devices Have an Unspecified Flaw in the Telnet Access Daemon That Lets Remote Users Cause Denial of Service Conditions
Version(s): prior to 11.21 (Cisco Aironet Access Point 340 and 350, Aironet Bridge 350)
Description:
Cisco reported a vulnerability in their Aironet wireless networking devices.  A remote user may be able to cause a denial of service condition.
A remote user can reportedly cause denial of service conditions if the Aironet device has Telnet access enabled.

Cisco reports that the following products running versions prior to 11.21 are vulnerable, but only when Telnet access is enabled:

   * Cisco Aironet Access Point 340 and 350
   * Cisco Aironet Bridge 350

The nature of the flaw was not described by the vendor.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions on the wireless device.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (11.21).  See the Source Message or the Vendor URL for instructions on how to obtain the update.

Cisco has also described a workaround, which is to disable Telnet access. You can accomplish this by following the link, via the web interface, path to reach the Console/Telnet Setup page:

   1.On the Summary Status page, click Setup. 

   2.On the Setup page, click Console/Telnet in the Services section of the page. 

   3.On that page, click on the radio button for Disable Telnet. 

Note: You must use the web interface or be connected on the console since you will be unable to save your changes if you are using Telnet. After disabling Telnet, your Telnet session will be terminated.

Title: (Cisco Metro 1500 DWDM is Vulnerable) 'zlib' Shared Compression Library Contains 'Double Free()' Buffer Overflow That Lets Remote Users Cause Programs Using zlib to Crash or Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the zlib shared library, a widely used library that provides in-memory compress and decompression functions.  A remote user could cause programs using this library to crash or to execute arbitrary code on the system.
It is reported that certain types of input will cause zlib to free the same area of memory twice (i.e., perform a "double free"), resulting in a buffer overflow condition when expanding compressed input. A remote user can cause programs that process untrusted user-supplied compressed input to crash or potentially execute arbitrary code on the system. 

Cisco reports that certain versions of their Metro 1500 DWDM multiplexer are vulnerable because they use the affected zlib library.  The following versions are vulnerable: versions prior to 3.3b.

It is reported that Matthias Clasen <maclas@gmx.de> and Owen Taylor <otaylor@redhat.com> discovered this bug in zlib.
Impact': A remote user can cause affected programs that use zlib to process untrusted user-supplied compressed input to crash or potentially execute arbitrary code on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (3.3b) for Metro 1500 DWDM.  It will be available on April 5, 2002, according to Cisco.

See the Source Message for the vendor's advisory containing directions on how to obtain the appropriate fix.

Title: RCA Cable Modem Denial of Service Error Lets Remote Users Reset the Device
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the RCA DCM225 cable modem.  A remote user can cause the modem to reset user connections.
A remote user can reportedly connect to port 80 on the device using the device's 10.x.x.x IP address to cause the modem to reset.  It is reported that a remote user can access this port on other user's modems in the same cable node.
Impact': A remote user can cause the modem to reset.  Doing this repeatedly can create a denial of service condition.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Foundry Networks EdgeIron Switches Let Remote Users Access SNMP With Any Community Name
Description:
A default configuration vulnerability was reported in the Foundry Networks EdgeIron switches.  An remote user can gain SNMP read and write access.
It is reported that the Foundry Networks EdgeIron 4802F Fast Ethernet switches uses a default SNMP configuration that allows a remote user to generate SNMP requests to the switch with any community string and gain read and write access to the system.
Impact': A remote user can gain read and write SNMP access to the system, even if the default SNMP communities have been deleted from the switch.
Solution:
According to the report, the fix from Foundry is to issue the following commands:

EdgeIron(config)#
EdgeIron(config)#snmp-server security
EdgeIron(config)#
EdgeIron(config)#snmp-server user <name> <community-string> <ip-address>

This then allows the specified IP to talk to the switch with that community string.  Requests from other IP's are ignored and the 'snmp-server security' option basically turns on the checking of SNMPv1 community strings.

Title: Foundry Networks ServerIron Web Filtering Rules Can Be Bypassed By Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Foundry Networks ServerIron web switches.  A remote user can bypass URI-based filtering rules.
It is reported that ServerIron switches do not decode URIs, so a remote user can submit an HTTP GET request using encoded URIs to bypass any ServerIron filtering rule sets.

For example, if a rule set is configured to direct requests for Perl scripts (with the '.pl' extension) to a specific server, the following URL will not be recognized as a request for a Perl script and the request may be sent to the wrong server:

http://[targethost]/index.%70%6c
Impact': A remote user can bypass URI-based filtering rules.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: Nortel Alteon ACEdirector Load Balancer May Disclose the Real and Otherwise Hidden IP Addresses of Load Balanced Servers to Remote Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in Nortel's Alteon ACEdirector web switching device.  In certain situations, the device may disclose the real IP addresses of "hidden" load-balanced web servers to remote users.
It is reported that a remote user can craft and send an HTTP request to the ACEdirector's virtual IP address to discover the real IP address or addresses of the "hidden" web servers that are being load-balanced.  If the device is configured for "Server Load Balancing" with the "Cookie-Based Persistence" feature, the vulnerability may be triggered.

The vulnerability is reportedly due to the mishandling of TCP streams from HTTP clients that use the TCP protocol's "half-close" feature.  The ACEdirector will apparently return packets from a hidden, load-balanced web server's real IP address to a client that establishes a connection to the ACEdirector's virtual IP address and then "half closes" the connection.
Impact': A remote user can determine the real IP addresses of hidden, load-balanced servers.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix in the following versions:  8.3.24.5, 9.0.41.5, 10.0.25.1.  These version should be available on the Nortel Support website shortly.

A fix is pending for the next build of versions 8.0 and 8.1 (8.0.63.5, 8.1.34.5). No fix is planned for older versions.

Title: Linksys Cable/DSL VPN Router Uses Weak IPSec Encryption Keys
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Linksys EtherFast BEFVP41 Cable/DSL VPN Router.  In certain situations, the router uses weak virtual private network (VPN) encryption keys.
It is reported that when using manually keyed IPSec VPNs with 3DES/MD5 keys, the router will truncate the keys.

For example, the following keys will be truncated as shown below:

Encryption: 80C4DAFD9AFC3D7AB57079E19DEBFFF43538A62039768D74
Authentication: 32EA72F58D7F1E063E14A3FF78131172

BEFVP41 truncated keys:

Encryption: 80C4DAFD9AFC3D7AB57079E
Authentication: 32EA72F58D7F1E063E1
Impact': Weak keys will be used if manually keyed IPSec is used.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor confirms the bug.  The vendor also notes that, when using IKE, full strength keys are used.

Title: Draytek Vigor DSL Router Leaves Undocumented Management Port Open on the External (Internet-side) Interface
Description:
A potential vulnerability was reported in the Draytek Vigor DSL router series.  The router has an undocumented open port that is accessible from the Internet.
It is reported that the Draytek Vigor 2000 series has an undocumented open port at 56415/tcp.  This port is apparently intended for use with a "smart start wizard".  In addition, the Draytek Vigor 2200 series with newer firmware, including a VPN option, leaves port 1723/tcp (typically used for PPTP) open even when not configured for VPN operation.

No vulnerability has been reported with the daemons listening on the open ports.
Impact': A remote user can access certain ports on the router that may not be used but still appear to be open.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicates that one possible workaround is to define rules in the router's firewall settings to block access to these unused ports.

Title: HP Procurve Switch Bug Allows Telnet Management Port to Be Temporarily Blocked for New Management Connections
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in HP's Procurve 4000M Ethernet switch.  A remote user can cause the telnet management port to temporarily stop accepting new management connections.
It is reported that a port scan (using nmap) performed against the management IP address of the HP Procurve switch will cause the telnet management port to stop accepting new connections for a temporary period of time.  After the port scan, port 23 reportedly remains open, but no text will be displayed when you connect to it.  After a few minutes, the switch will apparently be able to accept new incoming telnet management sessions.

It is reported that this does not affect the switch in any other way.  Existing telnet management connections, SNMP management 'sessions', console access, and traffic processing are reportedly not disrupted.

If the switch is rebooted, the telnet sevice will return to normal operations.

Any source IP address can apparently be used for the nmap portscan.

It is reported that firmware version C.07.01 does not appear to be vulnerable.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can cause the telnet management port on the switch to temporarily stop accepting new management connections for a period of a few minutes.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Cisco IOS-based Devices That Use Cisco Express Forwarding (CEF) May Leak Data from One Packet into Another Packet in Certain Situations
Description:
Cisco released an advisory warning of a vulnerability in all Cisco IOS-based devices that have Cisco Express Forwarding (CEF) enabled.  Information from previously processed packets may be leaked into other packets in certain situations.
It is reported that if the packet length described in the IP header is bigger than the actual MAC level physical packet size, then the packet will be expanded to fit the IP length.  Apparently, some data from previous packets may be inadvertently placed into the padded (expanded) section.

This vulnerability affects Cisco Express Forwarding (CEF) and not fast switching.

Cisco has assigned this vulnerability with Cisco Bug ID CSCdu20643 and, for the Cisco IOS 11.1CC image, with Cisco Bug ID CSCdp58360.
Impact': Partial information from a session processed by the router may be disclosed (at the packet level) to another session.
Solution:
Cisco has released a fix.  For a table showing the various product release trains and platforms that are affected, see the Vendor URL.

As a workaround, Cisco indicates that CEF can be disabled.

Title: (Motorola SURFboard Cable Modems are Vulnerable) Re: Many Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) Implementations Allow Remote Users to Deny Service or Obtain Access to the System
Description:
CERT reported that the University of Oulu (Finland) has discovered vulnerabilities in many vendor implementations of the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) version 1.
The Oulu University Secure Programming Group (OUSPG, http://www.ee.oulu.fi/research/ouspg/) reports that there are numerous vulnerabilities in SNMPv1 implementations from many different vendors. A remote user can reportedly cause denial of service attacks or gain elevated privileges on the system. The extent of the vulnerabilities depends on the specific vendor implementation. Vulnerabilities apparently include denial-of-service conditions, format string vulnerabilities, and buffer overflows. Some vulnerabilities do not require the request message to use the correct SNMP community string, according to CERT. OUSPG reportedly performed two sets of tests of SNMP request message handling of the decoded data.  Some of the products implement defective SNMPv1 trap handling. A remote user can reportedly send a specially crafted SNMP trap message to an SNMP manager to trigger the vulnerability. Some of the products implement defective SNMPv1 request handling. A remote user can reportedly send a specially crafted SNMP request message to an SNMP agent to trigger the vulnerability.

A user has reported that the OUSPG test case #900 can cause the cable modem to crash.
Impact': A remote user can cause the cable modem to crash.  The power must be cycled to return to normal operation.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: NETGEAR Router Denial of Service Vulnerability Lets Remote Users Crash the Device With a Port Scan
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the NETGEAR RM-356 router.  A remote user can cause the device to crash.
It is reported that a remote user can conduct a UDP port scan against the NETGEAR router to cause it to crashdump to the console.

The device tested uses network address translation (NAT) and has a V90 modem WAN interface.  The following commandline was used to trigger the flaw:

nmap -sU [ipaddress] -T5

The author of the report states that it appears that a scan to port 161/UDP is what causes the crash.
Impact': A remote user can cause the router to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (HP Confirms Bug) HP AdvanceStack Switching Hub Access Control Bug Lets Remote Users Gain Full Access to the Switch
Version(s): HP AdvanceStack J3200A, J3201A, J3202A, J3203A, J3204A, J3205A, J3210A with firmware version A.03.02
Description:
SecurityOffice.net reported a vulnerability in HP's AdvanceStack switching hub.  A remote user can gain full control of the switch.
It is reported that there is a flaw in the HP AdvanceStack J3210A that could allow a remote user to gain superuser access on the switch.

A remote user can apparently obtain access to the switch's password changing function (http://host/security/web_access.html) and change the superuser password.
Impact': A remote user can obtain superuser privileges on the hub.
Solution:
The vendor has confirmed the bug.  Another advisory will be issued when a fix is available.

The vendor has provided the following workaround:

There are two ways to work around the problem:

   1. Disable web access using telnet or RS-232 interface
      a. Telnet or console into switch
      b. Type "me" for menu
      c. Hit "2" for Management Access Configuration
      d. Hit "6" for Web enable/disable (verify it is disabled)

   2. Remove the management IP address
      a. Telnet or console into switch
      b. Type "me" for menu
      c. Hit "2" for Management Access Configuration
      d. Hit "1" for IP Configuration
      e. Hit "Y" to Change the IP configuration
      f. Choose "D" to disable segment
      g. Choose "D" to Disable (and verify it is disabled)
      (Repeat F & G for each IP assigned-segment as necessary.)

    NOTE! Disabling IP while connected via telnet will disconnect
          your session.

Title: ARESCOM NetDSL 800 Router Default Configuration Lets Remote Users Access the Telnet Management Port
Description:
A configuration vulnerability was reported in the ARESCOM NetDSL 800 router.  A remote user can connect to the router without authenticating and reconfigure it.
It is reported that the default configuration of the NetDSL 800 router does not require authentication on the telnet management port.  A remote user can gain access to the management console via telnet.
Impact': A remote user can gain management control of the router.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: ARESCOM NetDSL 1000 Router's Telnet Management Port Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the ARESCOM NetDSL 1000 router.  A remote user can cause the telnet management port to crash.
It is reported that the router has an open telnet port for the service provider to remotely reconfigure the router.  A remote user can reportedly send a long string (e.g., 256 'a' characters) to the telnet port to cause the login system to attempt to process the string as a valid login attempt.  After three unsuccessful attempts (which can apparently be generated with one long string), the router will close off the telnet connection.  A remote user can apparently flood the telnet port several dozen times to cause the telnet service to crash.

It is reported that the routing functions will continue to work.
Impact': A remote user can cause the telnet management port to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Announces Pending Fix) Re: Nortel Alteon ACEdirector Load Balancer May Disclose the Real and Otherwise Hidden IP Addresses of Load Balanced Servers to Remote Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in Nortel's Alteon ACEdirector web switching device.  In certain situations, the device may disclose the real IP addresses of "hidden" load-balanced web servers to remote users.
It is reported that a remote user can craft and send an HTTP request to the ACEdirector's virtual IP address to discover the real IP address or addresses of the "hidden" web servers that are being load-balanced.  If the device is configured for "Server Load Balancing" with the "Cookie-Based Persistence" feature, the vulnerability may be triggered.

The vulnerability is reportedly due to the mishandling of TCP streams from HTTP clients that use the TCP protocol's "half-close" feature.  The ACEdirector will apparently return packets from a hidden, load-balanced web server's real IP address to a client that establishes a connection to the ACEdirector's virtual IP address and then "half closes" the connection.
Impact': A remote user can determine the real IP addresses of hidden, load-balanced servers.
Solution: The vendor reports that this issue has been fixed and that the fix will be released for current software versions within 2 weeks.

Title: HP AdvanceStack Switching Hub Access Control Bug Lets Remote Users Gain Full Access to the Switch
Description:
SecurityOffice.net reported a vulnerability in HP's AdvanceStack switching hub.  A remote user can gain full control of the switch.
It is reported that there is a flaw in the HP AdvanceStack J3210A that could allow a remote user to gain superuser access on the switch.

A remote user can apparently obtain access to the switch's password changing function (http://host/security/web_access.html) and change the superuser password.
Impact': A remote user can obtain superuser privileges on the hub.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: CacheFlow CacheOS Discloses Some Cache Contents to Remote Users
Description:
Svindel.net reported an information disclosure vulnerability in the CacheFlow CacheOS.  A remote user can obtain some content being processed by the CacheFlow device from the device.
It is reported that a remote user can send certain requests to the web-admin interface to view parts of web pages and URLs that are being transferred through the cache.  This may include sensitive data, such as passwords and authentication tokens.

The following type of HTTP Request can be used against the admin port (8081):

GET /Secure/Local/console/cmhome.htm

This may require multiple attempts to obtain the information.  A demonstration exploit transcript is included in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can obtain chunks of web pages and URLs being processed by the cache.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  An updated version of the software is now available for all supported CacheFlow hardware platforms, and may be obtained by CacheFlow customers at the following URL:

http://download.cacheflow.com/

The vendor notes that the specific reference to the software update is contained within the Release Notes for CacheOS Versions 4.0.14, Release ID 17085 and 17087, as
follows:

http://download.cacheflow.com/release/SA/4.0.14/relnotes.htm
http://download.cacheflow.com/release/CA/4.0.14/relnotes.htm

Title: (A User Provides a Workaround) Re: NETGEAR Router Allows Cross Site Scripting Attacks, Possibly Allowing a Remote User to Gain Access to the Router
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the NETGEAR router series.  A remote user can conduct a cross-site scripting attack against the router.
It is reported that the router's web-based management interface allows cross site scripting attacks.  A remote user could create HTML content (either a web page or e-mail message) that contains the following type of URL:

http://<router_ip>/<script>alert('Vulnerable')</script>

If the content is sent to a router administrator and the URL is loaded on that administrator's browser, the javascript would execute within the security context of the router and could obtain the recipient's cookies associated with the router.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user could cause javascript to execute on another user's host that would be able to access the target user's cookies associated with the router management authentication.  This could potentially allow the remote user to gain access to the router.
Solution:
A user has reported the following workaround, apparently quoted from www.netgear.org in the "How to" section:

"Disalbing Internal HTTP, FTP and telnet Server of the Netgear to
protect it from all connection

Warning: This solution will disable TCP connection to Netgear box
completely (both LAN & WAN). You can make the change while you have
active telnet connection but as soon as you disconnect, you'll not be
able to access to the box via any TCP connection again (until reboot).
Routing functions work properly however.    

Goto 24.8 (CLI) interface and enter:

ip tcp mss 0

This will remain effective until reboot. If you want this permanent
you need to modify autoexec.net file on router. You can edit
autoexec.net via the following command.

sys edit autoexec.net

This is a line editor. Find the line that reads "ip tcp mss 512" and
replace 512 with 0. After reboot you will only access the router via
serial cable. If you don't have serial cable don't do this!

THIS WILL ALSO BLOCK DDNS UPDATE. IF YOU USE DDNS, DO NOT USE THAT TWEAK!

Credit goes to Tolunay from dslreports.com"

Title: NETGEAR Router Allows Cross Site Scripting Attacks, Possibly Allowing a Remote User to Gain Access to the Router
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the NETGEAR router series.  A remote user can conduct a cross-site scripting attack against the router.
It is reported that the router's web-based management interface allows cross site scripting attacks.  A remote user could create HTML content (either a web page or e-mail message) that contains the following type of URL:

http://<router_ip>/<script>alert('Vulnerable')</script>

If the content is sent to a router administrator and the URL is loaded on that administrator's browser, the javascript would execute within the security context of the router and could obtain the recipient's cookies associated with the router.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user could cause javascript to execute on another user's host that would be able to access the target user's cookies associated with the router management authentication.  This could potentially allow the remote user to gain access to the router.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: NETGEAR Router Web Content Filtering Mechanism Can Be Bypassed By Remote Users With Certain Malformed HTTP GET Requests
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NETGEAR's RO318 Cable/DSL Security Router.  A remote user can bypass the web content filtering restrictions.
It is reported that a remote user can send a malformed URL request through the router to access restricted web site URLs.  The web filtering component in firmware reportedly only checks for fully constructed requests.
Impact': A remote user can access restricted web content.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Cisco Issues Fix and Provides Workarounds) Re: Cisco Catalyst CatOS Telnet Daemon Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Crash and Reload the Switch
Description:
Cisco reported a buffer overflow vulnerability in their CatOS software for Catalyst switches.  A remote user can cause the switch to crash and reload.
It is reported that certain CatOS software releases have a buffer overflow vulnerability in the Telnet option handling.  A remote user can cause the Telnet daemon to crash, resulting in a switch reload.  This vulnerability can be repeatedly triggered to create a denial of service condition.

Cisco has documented this vulnerability as Cisco bug ID CSCdw19195.

The following Cisco Catalyst Switches are reported to be vulnerable:

     Catalyst 6000 series 
     Catalyst 5000 series 
     Catalyst 4000 series 
     Catalyst 2948G 
     Catalyst 2900 

See the Vendor URL for the Cisco advisory showing which specific releases are affected.

Cisco reports that the following Cisco Catalyst switches are not vulnerable:

     Catalyst 8500 series 
     Catalyst 4800 series 
     Catalyst 4200 series 
     Catalyst 3900 series 
     Catalyst 3550 series 
     Catalyst 3500 XL series 
     Catalyst 4840G 
     Catalyst 4908G-l3 
     Catalyst 2948G-l3 
     Catalyst 2950 
     Catalyst 2900 XL 
     Catalyst 2900 LRE XL 
     Catalyst 2820 
     Catalyst 1900
Impact': A remote user can cause the switch to crash and reload.  This can be performed repeatedly to deny service on the switch.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix, as described in an earlier alert. For more information on the fix, see the Cisco advisory:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/catos-telrcv-vuln-pub.shtml

Cisco has provided the following workarounds for the CatOS Telnet buffer overflow vulnerability:

1) Disable Telnet and use ssh instead (if ssh is available in the code base you are using).  For instructions, see:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/ssh_cat_switches.html

 2) User "IP Permit List" for Telnet to restrict access to the management interface to authorized and trusted IP addresses.  This reportedly will not prevent spoofed packets from reaching the interface.

For instructions, see:

http://www.cisco.com/univercd/cc/td/doc/product/lan/cat5000/rel_6_3/config/ip_perm.htm

3)  On the Catalyst 6000 series switches, use a VLAN Access Control List (ACL), if that feature is available, instead of using the IP Permit List workaround above.   Cisco notes that this, too, will not prevent spoofed IP packets from reaching the interface.

For instructions, see:

http://www.cisco.com/univercd/cc/td/doc/product/lan/cat6000/sft_6_1/configgd/acc_list.htm

4) Assign all of the management interfaces of all the switches in the network to a unique VLAN and apply access control lists on the router switching between the VLANs. 

For an example, see:

http://www.cisco.com/univercd/cc/td/doc/product/lan/cat6000/sft_6_1/configgd/acc_list.htm

5) Apply access control lists on routers, switches, and firewalls sitting in front of the CatOS switches to block Telnet access (port 23) from reaching the management interface.

For an example, see:

http://www.cisco.com/univercd/cc/td/doc/product/lan/cat6000/sft_6_1/configgd/acc_list.htm

Title: Cisco Catalyst CatOS Telnet Daemon Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Crash and Reload the Switch
Description:
Cisco reported a buffer overflow vulnerability in their CatOS software for Catalyst switches.  A remote user can cause the switch to crash and reload.
It is reported that certain CatOS software releases have a buffer overflow vulnerability in the Telnet option handling.  A remote user can cause the Telnet daemon to crash, resulting in a switch reload.  This vulnerability can be repeatedly triggered to create a denial of service condition.

Cisco has documented this vulnerability as Cisco bug ID CSCdw19195.

The following Cisco Catalyst Switches are reported to be vulnerable:

     Catalyst 6000 series 
     Catalyst 5000 series 
     Catalyst 4000 series 
     Catalyst 2948G 
     Catalyst 2900 

See the Vendor URL for the Cisco advisory showing which specific releases are affected.

Cisco reports that the following Cisco Catalyst switches are not vulnerable:

     Catalyst 8500 series 
     Catalyst 4800 series 
     Catalyst 4200 series 
     Catalyst 3900 series 
     Catalyst 3550 series 
     Catalyst 3500 XL series 
     Catalyst 4840G 
     Catalyst 4908G-l3 
     Catalyst 2948G-l3 
     Catalyst 2950 
     Catalyst 2900 XL 
     Catalyst 2900 LRE XL 
     Catalyst 2820 
     Catalyst 1900
Impact': A remote user can cause the switch to crash and reload.  This can be performed repeatedly to deny service on the switch.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  See the vendor's advisory for instruction on obtaining an upgrade, available at:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/catos-telrcv-vuln-pub.shtml

Title: Intel PRO/Wireless LAN Device Discloses Wireless Encryption Key to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Intel's PRO/Wireless 2011B Local Area Network (LAN) device.  A local user can view the wireless encryption protocol (WEP) key for the device.
It is reported that the WEP key is stored in plain text in the registry and is accessible to any local user.  The key is reportedly stored under the following type of Registry entry:

[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Control\Class\{4D36E972-E325-11CE-BFC1-08002BE10318}\0008]

Depending on the driver version, the key may be located in the DefaultKeys value:

"DefaultKeys"="364e01815b300d8038abc5ff00000000000000"

In this example, the first 12 hexadecimal values contain the 128-bit WEP key.
Impact': A local user can view the WEP key in the registry.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Nortel Alteon ACEdirector Load Balancer May Disclose the Real and Otherwise Hidden IP Addresses of Load Balanced Servers to Remote Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in Nortel's Alteon ACEdirector web switching device.  In certain situations, the device may disclose the real IP addresses of "hidden" load-balanced web servers to remote users.
It is reported that a remote user can craft and send an HTTP request to the ACEdirector's virtual IP address to discover the real IP address or addresses of the "hidden" web servers that are being load-balanced.  If the device is configured for "Server Load Balancing" with the "Cookie-Based Persistence" feature, the vulnerability may be triggered.

The vulnerability is reportedly due to the mishandling of TCP streams from HTTP clients that use the TCP protocol's "half-close" feature.  The ACEdirector will apparently return packets from a hidden, load-balanced web server's real IP address to a client that establishes a connection to the ACEdirector's virtual IP address and then "half closes" the connection.
Impact': A remote user can determine the real IP addresses of hidden, load-balanced servers.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

It is reported that the vendor opened a case (Nortel Networks Case Number 011211-76677; December 11, 2001) and then closed the case, determining that the vulnerability was not applicable to any real world scenario.

The author of the report has provided some workaround recommendations (see the Source Message).

Title: Dynalink RTA-020 ADSL Router Processing Can Be Halted By a Remote User Conducting a Port Scan Against the Router
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Dynalink RTA-020 ADSL Router.  A remote user can cause the router to hang.
It is reported that if a remote user conducts an nmap scan against the router or attempts to connect a certain number of times to the router, the router will stop processing traffic.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can cause the router to stop processing traffic.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Alcatel Speed Touch ADSL Router Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Conducting Operating System (OS) Detection Scans
Version(s): firmware version 8706, active software version GV8BAA3.253
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Alcatel's Speed Touch ADSL home router.  A remote user can cause the router to reboot.
It is reported that a remote user can conduct an nmap operating system detection scan against the router to cause it to reboot.

This can reportedly be achieved from the internal interface only.
Impact': A remote user can cause the router to reboot.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: NETGEAR RP-114 Cable/DSL Router Can Be Locked Up By Remote Users Conducting Port Scans
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the NETGEAR RP-114 Cable/DSL router.  A remote user can cause the router to lock up.
It is reported that a remote user can conduct a port scan using nmap on the WAN interface of the router to cause the router to lock up.  This has apparently been demonstrated when the router is configured for network address translation [NAT] and  port filtering to block all ports below 1024.

While the scan is being conducted, no traffic will be processed by the WAN port, according to the report.
Impact': A remote user can cause the router to temporarily lock up.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Fix is Available) Re: Linksys Cable/DSL Routers Disclose Information to Remote Users via SNMP Traps
Version(s): BEFN2PS4 (EtherFast Cable/DSL Router & Voice with 4-Port Switch), BEFSR81 (EtherFast Cable/DSL Router with 8-Port Switch), BEFSR41
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in several Linksys DSL/Cable routers.  A remote user can obtain SNMP traps.
It is reported that a remote user can query the router using the default SNMP community of 'public', which causes the router to set the querying IP address as the snmptrap host.  As a result, the following type of SNMP data will be sent to the querying IP address:

Enterprise Specific Trap (1) Uptime: 2 days, 19:00:23.36, enterprises.3955.1.1.0 = "@out 192.168.1.200 ==> 24.254.60.13[110]."
Enterprise Specific Trap (1) Uptime: 2 days, 19:00:23.36, enterprises.3955.1.1.0 = "@out 192.168.1.200 ==> 216.120.8.23[5632]."
Enterprise Specific Trap (1) Uptime: 2 days, 19:00:23.36, enterprises.3955.1.1.0 = "@out 192.168.1.200 ==> 216.120.8.3[5632]."
Enterprise Specific Trap (1) Uptime: 2 days, 19:00:23.36, enterprises.3955.1.1.0 = "@out 192.168.1.200 ==> 216.120.8.4[5632]."
Enterprise Specific Trap (1) Uptime: 2 days, 19:00:23.36, enterprises.3955.1.1.0 = "@out 192.168.1.200 ==> 216.120.8.5[5632]."
Enterprise Specific Trap (1) Uptime: 2 days, 6:04:38.11, enterprises.3955.1.1.0 = "-->[U]Send OP:    ^ps_status_q 15049C0DFC9B03166D55EA30474D04FB
 9218583272 a .."
Enterprise Specific Trap (1) Uptime: 2 days, 6:04:38.11, enterprises.3955.1.1.0 = "<--[U]Recv __:    ^ps_status_r.15049C0DFC9B03166D55EA30474D04FB.\

 The vendor has apparently been notified with no success.
Impact': A remote user can obtain potentially sensitive information from the router.
Solution:
A user reports that the vendor has confirmed that the BEFSR41 and BEFSR81 models are affected and that the latest firmware upgrades listed below correct the issues:

BEFSR41 - v1.40.2
BEFSR81 - v2.40.2

The user advises to contact support@linksys.com to see if your model is vulnerable and if the latest firmware corrects the issues.

Also, the user recommends that Linksys Cable/DSL router administrators should use Linklogger (http://www.linklogger.com/) to adequately monitor and log suspicious events.

Title: Cisco SN 5420 Storage Router Bugs Disclose the Router Configuration to Remote Users and Allow Remote Users to Crash the Router With Large HTTP Headers or Fragmented Packets
Description:
Cisco reported several vulnerabilities in their SN 5420 Storage Router series.  A remote user may be able to obtain the router's configuration file and can cause denial of service conditions.
It is reported that a remote user can view a stored configuration file on the Storage Router without the router requiring authentication if the configuration file has been previously saved on the router.

A remote user can reportedly send an HTTP request with "huge headers" to cause the Storage Router to crash.  A remote user can also cause the Storage Router to halt by sending a fragmented packet over the router's Gigabit interface.
Impact': A remote user may be able to obtain the router's configuration file.  A remote user can cause the router to crash.
Solution: The vendor has issued a fix in the release 1.1(7) of the software, which is available to Cisco customers via CCO.

Title: CacheFlow CacheOS Discloses Some Cache Contents to Remote Users
Description:
Svindel.net reported an information disclosure vulnerability in the CacheFlow CacheOS.  A remote user can obtain some content being processed by the CacheFlow device from the device.
It is reported that a remote user can send certain requests to the web-admin interface to view parts of web pages and URLs that are being transferred through the cache.  This may include sensitive data, such as passwords and authentication tokens.

The following type of HTTP Request can be used against the admin port (8081):

GET /Secure/Local/console/cmhome.htm

This may require multiple attempts to obtain the information.  A demonstration exploit transcript is included in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can obtain chunks of web pages and URLs being processed by the cache.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (A User Provides Some Details) Re: Linksys Cable/DSL Routers Disclose Information to Remote Users via SNMP Traps
Version(s): BEFN2PS4 (EtherFast Cable/DSL Router & Voice with 4-Port Switch), BEFSR81 (EtherFast Cable/DSL Router with 8-Port Switch)
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in several Linksys DSL/Cable routers.  A remote user can obtain SNMP traps.
It is reported that a remote user can query the router using the default SNMP community of 'public', which causes the router to set the querying IP address as the snmptrap host.  As a result, the following type of SNMP data will be sent to the querying IP address:

Enterprise Specific Trap (1) Uptime: 2 days, 19:00:23.36, enterprises.3955.1.1.0 = "@out 192.168.1.200 ==> 24.254.60.13[110]."
Enterprise Specific Trap (1) Uptime: 2 days, 19:00:23.36, enterprises.3955.1.1.0 = "@out 192.168.1.200 ==> 216.120.8.23[5632]."

Enterprise Specific Trap (1) Uptime: 2 days, 6:04:38.11, enterprises.3955.1.1.0 = "-->[U]Send OP:    ^ps_status_q 15049C0DFC9B03166D55EA30474D04FB

Enterprise Specific Trap (1) Uptime: 2 days, 6:04:38.11, enterprises.3955.1.1.0 = "<--[U]Recv __:    ^ps_status_r.15049C0DFC9B03166D55EA30474D04FB.\

 The vendor has apparently been notified with no success.
Impact': A remote user can obtain potentially sensitive information from the router.
Solution: A user reports that the v2.38.1 firmware release reportedly blocks the SNMP access on the WAN interface.  This would limit the exposure of this vulnerability to the internal (LAN) network.

Title: Linksys Cable/DSL Routers Disclose Information to Remote Users via SNMP Traps
Version(s): BEFN2PS4 (EtherFast Cable/DSL Router & Voice with 4-Port Switch), BEFSR81 (EtherFast Cable/DSL Router with 8-Port Switch)
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in several Linksys DSL/Cable routers.  A remote user can obtain SNMP traps.
It is reported that a remote user can query the router using the default SNMP community of 'public', which causes the router to set the querying IP address as the snmptrap host.  As a result, the following type of SNMP data will be sent to the querying IP address:
