 The vendor has apparently been notified with no success.
Impact': A remote user can obtain potentially sensitive information from the router.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Cisco uBR900 Series Cable Routers May Give Remote Users Read/Write Control of the Router
Description:
An access control vulnerability was reported in the Cisco uBR900 series cable access routers.  A remote user may be able to obtain read/write access to the device even after a DOCSIS configuration has been loaded.
It is reported that a remote user can obtain read/write access to the SNMP MIB using any community name.  This apparently occurs even though no SNMP RW (read/write) community is set.

The reports that Cisco has indicated that this behavior is required as part of the DOCSIS 1.0 specifications that cover cable routers.  The applicable text from the specification document (TP-OSSI-ATPv1.1-I01-011221 in section 2.1.7 CM Network management Access and SNMP Co-existence [OSS-07.1], 1 Default Access) apparently states:

"The Default Access test verifies the CM agent supports full SNMP access from an NSI side NMS and from a CPE side NMS after the CM completes registration with the basic1.cfg configuration file. The term "Default Access" implies no docsDevNmAccessTable row and no SNMPv3 configuration was supplied to the CM. Any SNMP read and any SNMP write community string can be used for this test, since compliant CMs will allow open access in the Default Access condition."

However, the report implies that a router on the Internet should have already satisfied the Default Access test and should only accept the SNMP community configuration specified in the loaded DOCSIS configuration file.
Impact': A remote user can gain read and write access to the device.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: ELSA Lancom Router Discloses the Administrator Password to Remote Users, Allowing Them to Change the Router's Configuration and Upload Modified Firmware
Version(s): ELSA Lancom 1100 Office (tested); other Lancom routers may also be affected
Description:
Phoenix Sistemi issued a security advisory warning of an information disclosure and access control vulnerability in the ELSA Lancom 1100 Office access router.  A remote user can obtain the administrator password, change routing tables, and upload modified firmware.
It is reported that the default configuration allows a remote user to connect to the router via port 80 with a web browser and obtain the remote access password, which is apparently stored in clear text.  The remote user can also change the router's configuration and can remotely upgrade the firmware.
Impact': A remote user can obtain the administrator password, change routing tables, and upload modified firmware.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report has provided the following recommendations:

- Change the configuration port. 
- Give access privileges during initial configuration to only internal ip addresses.
- Install a firewall with appropriate rules.

Title: D-Link DWL-1000AP Wireless Access Point SNMP Flaw Discloses the Administrator Password
Description:
An access control vulnerability was reported in the D-Link DWL-1000AP wireless router.  A remote user could obtain administrative control of the device.
A remote user can use the read-only SNMP community "public" to view the "admin password" in clear text in OID 1.3.6.1.4.1.937.2.1.2.2.0 as a string value.  The remote user can then use that admin password to access the device and change the configuration.  The remote user can use SNMP to reset the password and then login via HTTP to make further configuration changes.
Impact': A remote user can view the administrative password and then gain control of the device.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor reportdly does not believe there should be much concern over this flaw.

Title: Linksys Wireless Access Point SNMP Port Can Be Locked Out By Remote Users
Version(s): Atmel Firmware 1.3; Tested on a WAP11 Syslink Wireless Access Point WPC11 Wireless network PC card (PCMCIA+PCI) Under Windows 2000
Description:
VIGILANTe reported a denial of service vulnerability in the WAP11 Syslink Wireless Access Point WPC11 Wireless network PC card.  A remote user can cause the device's SNMP port to crash.
A remote user can send an SNMP read request with a community name different than "public", including a NULL community string, or with an unknown OID to cause the device's SNMP port to stop processing requests.  This apparently occurs even if the SNMP response sent by the device is correct.

It is reported that the vendor has released a more recent version of this software, but it is not known if it is vulnerable to this attack.  VIGILANTe did not perform tests on this newer version.
Impact': A remote user can cause the device's SNMP port to stop processing requests.
Solution:
The vednor has released a newer version of the firmware (1.4g.5).  The vendor suggests using the new code, available at:

ftp://ftp.linksys.com/pub/network/wap11fw14g5.exe.

A new utility is also required to use this firmware, available at:

ftp://ftp.linksys.com/pub/network/wap11sw.exe.

Note that VIGILANTe did not test the newer version.  Also, the vendor does not explicitly state that the newer version corrects the situation.

Title: ZyXEL Prestige SDSL Router Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending Malformed Packets
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability has been reported in ZyXEL's Prestige SDSL routers.  A remote user can cause the router to hang by sending malformed packets.
It is reported that a remote user can send certain malformed packets to the router on the DSL-interface side of the router to cause it to hang.  This reportedly cannot be triggered from the internal Ethernet interface side of the router.  When the vulnerability is triggered, ZyNOS apparently reports that the line is synchronizing.  It may take between 2 and 3 mintues before the link comes back up and operations return to normal.

The nature of the malformed packets required to exploit this flaw was not disclosed.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can cause the router to stop processing traffic for several minutes.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report presents a workaround:

"The workaround is to switch off routing and put device in bridging mode."

Title: SpeedXess DSL Router Uses Common Default Password
Description:
A default configuration vulnerability was reported in the Hyundai Networks SpeedXess DSL Router.  A remote user can access the router if the common default password has not been changed.
The SpeedXess HASE-120 ADSL Router uses a common default password that can be readily guessed by remote users.  The default password is reported to be "speedxess".
Impact': A remote user can access the router and change the router's configuration settings if the common default password has not been changed.
Solution: Be sure to change the default password.

Title: Cisco IOS Firewall Feature Contains Packet Inspection Flaw That Allows Remote Users to Send Unauthorized Packets Through the Firewall in Certain Situations
Version(s): 11.2P, 11.3T, 12.0, 12.0T, 12.1, 12.1T, 12.1E, 12.2, 12.2T; some Early Deployment ("X releases") are also affected -- see the Vendor URL
Description:
Cisco issued a notice warning of a vulnerability in the Cisco IOS Firewall feature set.  A remote user may be able to pass unauthorized IP packets through the firewalled-router in certain situations.
When a session is initiated from the protected network, the firewall software creates a dynamic access list entry to allow the return traffic for that session to enter from the untrusted network.  When an incoming packet arrives from the untrusted network and is inspected by the router against the dynamic access list, the source and destination addresses and ports are checked but the IP protocol type is not checked.  A remote user could exploit this vulnerability and send IP packets of a different protocol type through the firewalled-router.

The following hardware models are affected:  Cisco routers in the following series: 800, 820, 950, 1400, 1600, 1700, 2500, 2600, 3600, 4000 Gateway, 4224, 7100, 7200, 7400, 7500, SOHO 70, ubr900, ICS7750; and the Catalyst 5000 and 6000 if they are running Cisco IOS software.

This vulnerability has been documented as Cisco Bug ID CSCdv48261.
Impact': A remote user may be able to pass unauthorized IP packets through the firewalled-router in certain situations.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  A table listing the various affected versions and the applicable upgrades is available at the Vendor URL and is contained in the Source Message.

Title: Cisco Internetwork Operating System (IOS)-based Router ARP Processing Can Be Crashed, Adversely Affecting Management Communications With the Router
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Version(s): A list of affected IOS versions is provided in the Source Message
Description:
Cisco released an advisory warning of a vulnerability in their Cisco IOS operating system software.  A remote user can cause the router's Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) table to be overwritten.
A remote user on a local network interface could create an ARP packet that will cause a device running Cisco IOS or CatOS to stop processing ARP packets on that local segment.

It is reported that a remote user can generate ARP packets and send them to a router's interface address with a different Media Access Control (MAC) address to cause the router's MAC address in the ARP table to be overwritten with the one from the received ARP packet.  This will cause the ARP processing to stop.

This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco Bug ID CSCdu81936.
Impact': A remote user on a local network segment can overwrite entries in the router's ARP table and can cause the router's ARP processing to crash, resulting in denial of service of management communications with the router.  The vendor claims that normal traffic processing is not affected.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  See the Vendor URL or the Source Message to determine the appropriate release for your product and version of IOS.

The vendor has also released a workaround:

"Enter the router interface MAC address into the arp table with a configuration entry, sometimes known as "hard coding" the ARP table entry. 

The syntax for this command for routers and switches running IOS is as follows: 

     arp <ip-address> <hardware-address> <type>

The syntax for this command for switches running CatOS is as follows: 

     set arp [dynamic|permanent|static] <ip_address> <hardware_address>

The caveat to this workaround is identified with defect CSCdv04366, which will clear all manually entered MAC addresses from the ARP table, when they are the same as the interface MAC address, when the command "clear arp" is issued on the router.  This workaround does not survive a reboot of the router, and must be re-written to the configuration after any reload or reboot."

Title: Cisco 12000 Series Internet Routers May Fail to Enforce Access Control Lists, Allowing Remote Users to Bypass the Packet Filtering Security Rules
Version(s): Certain versions using Engine 2 line cards only
Description:
Cisco reported some access control vulnerabilities in their Cisco 12000 Series Internet Routers.  A remote user could bypass the access control rules and pass packets through the router.
Cisco reports that there are six vulnerabilities involving Access Control List (ACL) in the Cisco 12000 Series Internet Routers. Only Cisco 12000 Series Internet Routers with line cards based on "Engine 2" are affected with these vulnerabilities.  To determine which Engine your card is based on, customers can use the "sh diag" command while in enable mode to display the engine number (e.g., "L3 Engine: x," where x is the Engine number).  An example display is included in the advisory, available at the Vendor URL and shown in the Source Message.

In one case, initial IP packet fragments may not be blocked.  In another case, the implicit "deny ip any any" rule at the end of an ACL is not enforced if an ACL of exactly 448 entries is applied on an interface as an outgoing ACL.  In another case, an outbound ACL may fail to block some traffic when another input ACL is configured on some, but not all, interfaces of a multi port Engine 2 line card (in this case, the traffic that is not blocked must not have been filtered by an inbound ACL on the ingress port).  Additional details about each of the six vulnerabilities is provided in the Source Message.

Cisco has assigned these bug ID numbers CSCdm44976, CSCdu57417, CSCdu03323, CSCdu35175, CSCdt96370, and CSCdt69741.
Impact': A remote user can send packets that will bypass the access control list rules.
Solution: The vendor has released fixed versions.  A table listing the various available fixes is provided in the vendor's advisory, available at the Vendor URL and shown in the Source Message.

Title: Cisco 12000 Series Internet Routers Can Be Degraded or Crashed By Remote Users Due to CPU Overloading in Generating ICMP Unreachable Messages
Version(s): Line cards based on Engines 0, 1 and 2 are vulnerable -- see the Description for details
Description:
Cisco reported a vulnerability in their 12000 series Internet routers.  A remote user can degrade performance of the router by sending a large number of packets that require the router to respond with ICMP Unreachable messages.
When a remote user sends a high volume of traffic to the router that requires the router to generate ICMP Unreachable replies, the processing of the replies can reportedly saturate the CPU.  This condition can apparently occur when the router is configured for "Black Hole" filtering (i.e., dropping packets sent to the router as the network's default path -- see the Source Message for additional details on this) or when a direct denial of service attack is targeted against the router.

Cisco reports that not all line cards of a Cisco 12000 Series are affected by this vulnerability.  To determine the "Engine" your card is based on and whether you are affected, administrators can issue the "sh diag" command while in enable mode.  The engine number will be displayed (e.g., "L3 Engine: x", where x is the engine number.  An example of this display is included in the Source Message.  It is reported that line cards based on Engines 0, 1 and 2 are vulnerable and that line cards based on Engine 3 and 4 are not vulnerable.

Cisco reports that some Internet Service Providers (ISPs) have experienced degradation due to this vulnerability.

Cisco has assigned this vulnerability the following bug IDs: CSCdr46528, CSCdt66560, and CSCds36541.
Impact': A remote user can cause the router's performance to degrade and, in the worst case scenario, cause the router to stop forwarding packets.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  A table showing the fixed release version numbers for the various release trains is in the advisory, available at the Vendor URL or as shown in the Source Message.

Title: (Cisco Updates Information) Re: Cisco IOS Router Flaw in Processing Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) Messages Allows Remote Users on the Local Network to Cause the Device to Crash
Version(s): All releases, prior fixed releases, of IOS and CatOS are vulnerable. All Catalyst models are vulnerable.
Description:
Phenoelit Group issued an advisory warning of a denial service vulnerability in Cisco IOS.  A resource error allows a remote user on the local network to cause the router to consume all available memory and then crash.
When a Cisco IOS router receives a flood of Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) neighbor announcement messages, IOS reportedly consumes all available memory and then crashes or reboots.

Cisco has reported that this issue also affects CatOS (inaddition to IOS, which was previously announced).  Cisco has assigned this vulnerability bug ID CSCdu09909 for Cisco IOS and CSCdv57576 for CatOS.

An updated Vendor URL has been provided to point directly to Cisco's notes on the topic.

For details on the vulnerability, see the original Alert in the Message History.
Impact': A remote user on the same local area network segment can cause some IOS devices on the segment to crash.
Solution:
This vulnerability has reportedly been fixed in the following interim Cisco IOS releases:

     12.2(3.6)B
     12.2(4.1)S
     12.2(3.6)PB
     12.2(3.6)T
     12.1(10.1)
     12.2(3.6)

All later Cisco IOS releases should contain this fix. 

Cisco has provided a workaround for the vulnerability:

The workaround for this vulnerability is to disable CDP. CDP can be disabled either for the whole device or on a selected links. In order to disable CDP for the whole router, execute the following global command: 

     Router# configure terminal
     Enter configuration commands, one per line.  End with CNTL/Z.
     Router(config)# no cdp run

Alternatively, CDP can be disabled on a particular interface. This can be done using the following commands: 

     Router# configure terminal
     Enter configuration commands, one per line.  End with CNTL/Z.
     Router(config)# interface Ethernet0
     Router(config-if)# no cdp enable

To disable CDP for the whole Catalyst, execute the following command: 

     Console> (enable) set cdp disable

Alternatively, CDP can be disabled on a particular interface. In this example CDP is disabled for the port 23 on a module 1: 

     Console> (enable) set cdp disable 1/23

In this particular case, Cisco Systems advises all customers to disable CDP for the whole device. If you must keep CDP running for any purpose then you should consider disabling it on all interfaces/ports that are facing host farms or outward of your administrative domain (for example, toward an upstream Internet Service Provider (ISP) or xdigital subscriber line (xDSL) customers). 

The vendor has not released estimated dates for when fixed versions of CatOS will be available.

Title: (Cisco Responds) Re: Cisco IOS Router Flaw in Processing Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) Messages Allows Remote Users on the Local Network to Cause the Device to Crash
Version(s): Cisco 1005 IOS 11.1.*, Cisco 1603 IOS 11.2, 11.3.11b, Cisco 2503 IOS 12.0.19, Cisco 2600 IOS 12.1.?, Catalyst 2940XL IOS 12.0(5.1)XP; possibly others
Description:
Phenoelit Group issued an advisory warning of a denial service vulnerability in Cisco IOS.  A resource error allows a remote user on the local network to cause the router to consume all available memory and then crash.
When a Cisco IOS router receives a flood of Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) neighbor announcement messages, IOS reportedly consumes all available memory and then crashes or reboots.

The Cisco Discovery Protocol is a layer two protocol.  Cisco IOS apparently sends out CDP frames via Ethernet to the multicast address 01:00:0C:CC:CC:CC.  It is reported that when an IOS-based device receives a CDP frame from another device, it stores the contents in an internal data structure.  When two identical but long device IDs are received, some IOS versions apparently fail to identify them as identical and then store both of them as independent records. 

A remote user on the same local area network (LAN) segment can flood a LAN segment with large CDP frames containing a random device ID and originating from a random data link address to cause some IOS devices to crash or reboot.

An example exploit transcript is provided in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly assigned Cisco bug ID CSCdu09909 to this issue.  At the time of this entry, Cisco has not yet released their advisory covering this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user on the same local area network segment can cause some IOS devices on the segment to crash.
Solution:
Cisco has provided a workaround and has issued an interim fix.

According to Cisco, the workaround is to disable CDP via the following methods:

In order to disable CDP for the whole router execute the following global command:

  Router# configure terminal
  Enter configuration commands, one per line.  End with CNTL/Z.
  Router(config)# no cdp run

Alternatively, CDP can be disabled on a particular interface. This
can be done using the following commands:

  Router# configure terminal
  Enter configuration commands, one per line.  End with CNTL/Z.
  Router(config)# interface Ethernet0
  Router(config-if)# no cdp enable

Cisco advises that all customers should disable CDP for the whole router.

The vendor notes that this vulnerability has been corrected in the following interim images:

12.2(3.6)B
12.2(4.1)S
12.2(3.6)PB
12.2(3.6)T
12.1(10.1)
12.2(3.6)

The vendor notes that all higher IOS releases should contain this fix.

Title: Cisco IOS Router Flaw in Processing Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) Messages Allows Remote Users on the Local Network to Cause the Device to Crash
Version(s): Cisco 1005 IOS 11.1.*, Cisco 1603 IOS 11.2, 11.3.11b, Cisco 2503 IOS 12.0.19, Cisco 2600 IOS 12.1.?, Catalyst 2940XL IOS 12.0(5.1)XP; possibly others
Description:
Phenoelit Group issued an advisory warning of a denial service vulnerability in Cisco IOS.  A resource error allows a remote user on the local network to cause the router to consume all available memory and then crash.
When a Cisco IOS router receives a flood of Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP) neighbor announcement messages, IOS reportedly consumes all available memory and then crashes or reboots.

The Cisco Discovery Protocol is a layer two protocol.  Cisco IOS apparently sends out CDP frames via Ethernet to the multicast address 01:00:0C:CC:CC:CC.  It is reported that when an IOS-based device receives a CDP frame from another device, it stores the contents in an internal data structure.  When two identical but long device IDs are received, some IOS versions apparently fail to identify them as identical and then store both of them as independent records. 

A remote user on the same local area network (LAN) segment can flood a LAN segment with large CDP frames containing a random device ID and originating from a random data link address to cause some IOS devices to crash or reboot.

An example exploit transcript is provided in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly assigned Cisco bug ID CSCdu09909 to this issue.  At the time of this entry, Cisco has not yet released their advisory covering this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user on the same local area network segment can cause some IOS devices on the segment to crash.
Solution: Cisco has apparently created a fix, which is pending.  At the time of this entry, Cisco had not posted their advisory.  See the Message History for an Alert containing the Cisco advisory (when it becomes available).

Title: 3Com HomeConnect Cable Modem Can Be Reset or Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability has been reported in 3Com's HomeConnect Cable Modem.  Remote users can cause the router to crash or to reset.
It is reported that the device has port 80/TCP enabled and accessible via the Internet-side interface.  A remote user can send a request for a filename with more than 100 characters to cause the router to be reset or to crash.

An example URL that will trigger the vulnerability is:

http://target3comcablemodem/<AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA+100CHARS>
Impact': A remote user can cause the router to reset or to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The report notes that users can filter (block) port 80 to mitigate the vulnerability.

Title: ZyXEL ADSL Router Filters Fail to Block Internal Administrative Access
Version(s): ZyXEL 642R ADSL Router: ZyNOS Firmware Version 2.50(AJ.4, 7.3.2001); possibly others
Description:
An access control vulnerability was reported in the ZyXEL 642R ADSL router.  When filters are used to protect the administrative Telnet and FTP interfaces, the filter fails to block internal network access to those services.
It is reported that a remote user can access the administrative Telnet and FTP interfaces of the router even if filters are in place to block these connections by connecting to the WAN-side IP address instead of the LAN-side address.  

It may be difficult to create filters to block these internal LAN-originated connections on the WAN-side interface when the WAN is using DHCP addresses that constantly change.
Impact': A remote user on the internal network can obtain Telnet and FTP port access to the router even when LAN-side filters are in place.  Note that the remote user must still know the password to gain access to the router.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Cisco Internet Content Distribution Network (iCDN) Products May Let Remote Users Masquerade as Valid Authenticated Clients Due to Security Flaw in RSA BSAFE Library
Description:
Cisco reported a vulnerability in their Internet Content Distribution Network (iCDN) product, due to a flaw in an RSA library used by iCDN.  Remote users may be able to masquerade as valid authenticated users.
Cisco reported a vulnerability in their Internet Content Distribution Network (iCDN) product.  This flaw is due to an underlying flaw in the RSA BSAFE SSL-J toolkit that was apparently used in buiding the iCDN product (see separate Alert on BSAFE).

Cisco reports that iCDN 1.0 is not vulnerable because it does not contain the RSA BSAFE SSL-J library.

For details on the BSAFE vulnerability, see the separate Alert.

Cisco provided the following information on the BSAFE vulnerability:

   "A security vulnerability has been discovered in version 3.x of the RSA
   BSAFE SSL-J Software Developer Kit made by RSA Security. This
   vulnerability enables an attacker to establish a Secure Socket Layer
   (SSL) session with the server, bypassing the client authentication and
   using a bogus client certificate. The server must have been developed
   using a vulnerable RSA BSAFE SSL-J Software Development Kit (SDK).
   Servers based on other libraries are not known to be vulnerable to
   this issue. For further details regarding this vulnerability, see
   http://www.rsasecurity.com/support/bsafe/index.html"

Cisco has designated this vulnerability as Cisco Bug ID CSCdu68211.
Impact': A remote user without valid client certificate credentials may be able to masquerade as a different authenticated user.
Solution: Obtain the new version.  This vulnerability has been fixed in release 2.0.1.  See the Vendor URL for upgrade instructions.

Title: D-Link Dl-704 DSL Router Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending Improperly Fragmented IP Packets
Description:
Fate Research Labs reported a vulnerability in the D-Link Dl-704 DSL router that allows remote users to cause the router to crash.
A remote user can reportedly generate a large number of identical/incorrectly fragmented IP packets to cause the router to stop forwarding packets.  A reboot is required to return to normal operation.
Impact': A remote user can cause the DSL router to crash.
Solution:
Download new firmware.  It is reported that version V2.56b6 or later will fix the flaw.  It is available at:

http://www.dlink.com.tw/2000e/download/download.htm

Title: Marconi ASX Series ATM Switches Allow Remote Users to Crash the Telnet Administrative Interface
Version(s): Hardware tested:  Marconi ASX-200, P5 cpu, Software version: ForeThought 71.1.0_1.83325.bin
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in Marconi's ASX series ATM switches that allows a remote user to crash the telnet administrative interface.
A remote user can apparently conduct an nmap RPCgrind scan against the telnet port to cause it to lock up.  Once locked up, a reboot is required to return the telnet daemon to working condition.

This is reportedly unrelated to a previous administrative denial of service issue with the ForeThought TCP/IP stack.
Impact': A remote user can cause the telnet administrative interface to lock up.
Solution:
The vendor is reportedly working on a fix.

As a workaround, telnet access to Marconi ASX switches can be restricted to management networks.

Title: Cisco 600 Series DSL Routers (CBOS Operating System) Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Via Administrative Interface
Description:
Cisco reported a vulnerability in their Cisco Broadband Operating System (CBOS) for their 600 Series DSL routers that allows remote users to crash the router by connecting to the administrative interface.
A remote user can send a large amount of HTTP traffic to the web-based configuration utility port (port 80 by default) to cause the router to stop processing traffic, regardless of whether the web-based configuration utility is enabled.

A remote user can also send multiple telnet connections to the router configuration port to cause the router to crash.

In both cases, the router will reportedly fail to process traffic and may fail to accept configuration attempts.

These flaws have been assigned Cisco Bug IDs CSCdv06084, CSCdv06088, CSCdv06089, and CSCdv06098.
Impact': A remote user can open multiple HTTP or Telnet connections to the router to cause it to crash.  A reboot is required to return to normal operation.
Solution: Cisco has released CBOS 2.4.3 to fix the vulnerabilities.  See the Vendor URL for information on obtaining the upgrade.

Title: (Vendor Has Issued a Fix) Re: Linksys EtherFast Router Discloses Usernames and Passwords Via the Network
Description:
The Linksys EtherFast 4-Port Cable/DSL Router is reported to contain a design vulnerability that discloses usernames and passwords via the network.
It is reported that the login passwords for both the router and the user's ISP are embedded in cleartext in the index.html and Passwd.htm HTML source code.  A user sniffing the local network can view the usernames and passwords.
Impact': A remote user sniffing the local network can view usernames and passwords and can then access the device and the user's ISP account.
Solution:
The vendor has reportedly released an update of their firmware for their 1,4 and USB port routers to version 1.39.3BETA to fix the password retrieval vulnerability.

http://www.practicallynetworked.com/support/linksys_router_help_pg2.htm#Firmware

Title: (Info on Additional Vulnerable Models) Re: Some ZyXEL Prestige Routers Allow Remote Telnet and FTP Access to the Device in the Default Configuration
Version(s): ZyXEL Prestige 642R and 642R-I, V2.50(AJ.4), V2.50(AL.1), V2.50(AL.2)b2; also ZyXEL Prestige 100, 202
Description:
A configuration vulnerability was reported in some ZyXEL Prestige routers that allows remote users to access the router's Telnet and FTP services in the default configuration.
In the default configuration, the P642R and P642R-I ADSL routers have the administrative Telnet and FTP services exposed on the WAN (Internet) side.  In addition, a common default password is used.  It is reported that a significant proportion of users do not change the default password.  This allows a remote user to access the device and make modifications to the device's configuration and firmware.

Since the release of firmware version AJ.3, WAN side filters for Telnet and FTP are apparently intended to be in place in the default configuration.  However, that is not the case.

It is reported that the ZyXEL Prestige 642M is not vulnerable.

The P642R and 642R-I models when used in "bridge mode" with PPPoE are reported to be not vulnerable.
Impact': A remote user can gain administrative access to the router when in the default configuration.  Administrative access allows the user to make configuration changes and upload new firmware.
Solution:
Users can apply the FTP_WAN and TELNET_WAN filter rules to block incoming connections to ports 21 and 23.  This can reportedly be done by hooking filter rules 3 and 5 into the Remote Node Setup (menu 11.1 -> 11.5), like so:

                         Menu 11.5 - Remote Node Filter

                    Input Filter Sets:
                      protocol filters=3,5
                        device filters=
                    Output Filter Sets:
                      protocol filters=
                        device filters=

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: Some ZyXEL Prestige Routers Allow Remote Telnet and FTP Access to the Device in the Default Configuration
Version(s): ZyXEL Prestige 642R and 642R-I, V2.50(AJ.4), V2.50(AL.1), V2.50(AL.2)b2
Description:
A configuration vulnerability was reported in some ZyXEL Prestige routers that allows remote users to access the router's Telnet and FTP services in the default configuration.
In the default configuration, the P642R and P642R-I ADSL routers have the administrative Telnet and FTP services exposed on the WAN (Internet) side.  In addition, a common default password is used.  It is reported that a significant proportion of users do not change the default password.  This allows a remote user to access the device and make modifications to the device's configuration and firmware.

Since the release of firmware version AJ.3, WAN side filters for Telnet and FTP are apparently intended to be in place in the default configuration.  However, that is not the case.

It is reported that the ZyXEL Prestige 642M is not vulnerable.

The P642R and 642R-I models when used in "bridge mode" with PPPoE are reported to be not vulnerable.
Impact': A remote user can gain administrative access to the router when in the default configuration.  Administrative access allows the user to make configuration changes and upload new firmware.
Solution: The vendor has issued a fix.  See the Source Message for information on the new firmware releases.

Title: (Information About a Fixed Version) Re: Some ZyXEL Prestige Routers Allow Remote Telnet and FTP Access to the Device in the Default Configuration
Version(s): ZyXEL Prestige 642R and 642R-I, V2.50(AJ.4), V2.50(AL.1), V2.50(AL.2)b2
Description:
A configuration vulnerability was reported in some ZyXEL Prestige routers that allows remote users to access the router's Telnet and FTP services in the default configuration.
In the default configuration, the P642R and P642R-I ADSL routers have the administrative Telnet and FTP services exposed on the WAN (Internet) side.  In addition, a common default password is used.  It is reported that a significant proportion of users do not change the default password.  This allows a remote user to access the device and make modifications to the device's configuration and firmware.

Since the release of firmware version AJ.3, WAN side filters for Telnet and FTP are apparently intended to be in place in the default configuration.  However, that is not the case.

It is reported that the ZyXEL Prestige 642M is not vulnerable.

The P642R and 642R-I models when used in "bridge mode" with PPPoE are reported to be not vulnerable.
Impact': A remote user can gain administrative access to the router when in the default configuration.  Administrative access allows the user to make configuration changes and upload new firmware.
Solution: The author of the original report notes that the vendor has added and applied a working filter rule and changed the default filtering configuration. The default password did not change.  As of firmware 2.50(AJ.4) for the 642R, released in July, there is reportedly a filter rule active in the default configuration that blocks incoming ports 21/tcp, 23/tcp, 80/tcp, and 69/udp on the WAN side.

Title: (Some Details are Clarified) Re: Some ZyXEL Prestige Routers Allow Remote Telnet and FTP Access to the Device in the Default Configuration
Version(s): ZyXEL Prestige 642R and 642R-I, V2.50(AJ.4), V2.50(AL.1), V2.50(AL.2)b2
Description:
A configuration vulnerability was reported in some ZyXEL Prestige routers that allows remote users to access the router's Telnet and FTP services in the default configuration.
The author of the original report clarifies and corrects the details of the vulnerability.

For the original report, see the Message History.

For the corrected details, see the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can gain administrative access to the router when in the default configuration.  Administrative access allows the user to make configuration changes and upload new firmware.
Solution:
Users can apply the FTP_WAN and TELNET_WAN filter rules to block incoming connections to ports 21 and 23.  This can reportedly be done by hooking filter rules 3 and 5 into the Remote Node Setup (menu 11.1 -> 11.5), like so:

                         Menu 11.5 - Remote Node Filter

                    Input Filter Sets:
                      protocol filters=3,5
                        device filters=
                    Output Filter Sets:
                      protocol filters=
                        device filters=

Version(s): ZyXEL Prestige 642R and 642R-I, V2.50(AJ.4), V2.50(AL.1), V2.50(AL.2)b2
Description:
A configuration vulnerability was reported in some ZyXEL Prestige routers that allows remote users to access the router's Telnet and FTP services in the default configuration.

                    Output Filter Sets:
                      protocol filters=
                        device filters=

Title: Linksys EtherFast Router Discloses Usernames and Passwords Via the Network
Description:
The Linksys EtherFast 4-Port Cable/DSL Router is reported to contain a design vulnerability that discloses usernames and passwords via the network.
It is reported that the login passwords for both the router and the user's ISP are embedded in cleartext in the index.html and Passwd.htm HTML source code.  A user sniffing the local network can view the usernames and passwords.
Impact': A remote user sniffing the local network can view usernames and passwords and can then access the device and the user's ISP account.
Solution: No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  As a workaround, a user can administer the router from a workstation that is directly connected to one of the switch ports and add a static arp cache entry for the router on the workstation to deny any arp cache poisioning which would work to sniff across the switch.

Title: Cisco LocalDirector Load Balancer May Allow Remote Users to Deny Service in Certain Configurations
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Cisco's LocalDirector load balancers that, in certain configurations, allows a remote user to place a load balanced server out of service by port scanning the virtual IP (VIP).
The vulnerability can reportedly be triggered if the LocalDirector is configured to perform all port mappings (0:0) rather than port-bound virtuals (port-to-port mappings).  A remote user can cause the "no answer reassign" counter to exceed its default threshold of eight.

If a remote user conducts a port scan of a 0:0 VIP where the real servers are not listening to all ports, the "no answer reassign" counter can surpass the threshold, taking the real machine out of service.  If this attack is performed against all servers in a VIP, the VIP will become unresponsive until it is reset.
Impact': A remote user can cause load balanced servers to be placed out of service by a LocalDirector.
Solution: Cisco confirms the condition and recommends that customers use port-bound VIPs or make certain that VIPs are protected by a firewall in front of the LocalDirector.

Title: 3Com SuperStack II Switches Fail to Restrict Telnet Login Failures, Making it Possible for Remote Users to Perform Unimpeded Brute Force Password Guessing Attacks to Obtain Administrative Access to the Device
Version(s): tested on a PS40 SuperStack II
Description:
It is reported that 3Com's hardware does not limit the number of unsuccessful telnet authentication attempts and does not introduce a delay between failed attempts when Telnet configuration is enabled.
A demonstration Perl exploit script is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can conduct an unimpeded brute force password guessing attempt to obtain administrative access to the device.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (CIAC Issues Advisory L-112) Re: Cisco SN 5420 Storage Router Gives Special Administrative Access to Remote Users and Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
Cisco reports that two vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Cisco SN 5420 Storage Router.  One allows remote users to cause the router to reboot and the other allows remote users to obtain special administrative access to the router.
A remote user can cause the device to reboot by rapidly establishing multiple connections to TCP port 8023.          
A remote user can access a developer's shell account on the device by using rlogin (port 513) or connecting to port 8023 from the GigabitEthernet or management interface.  It is reported that no authentication is required.  The user's login and all commands executed by the user are not logged.

The vulnerabilities have been assigned Cisco Bug IDs CSCdu27529 and CSCdu27514.
Impact':
A remote user can prevent users from accessing storage.

A remote user (exploiting the developer's shell vulnerability) can execute debug commands, start and stop processes, and interfere with the normal process execution.
Solution: The vendor has provided a fixed version 1.1(4).  See the Vendor URL for information on obtaining the upgrade.

Title: Cisco IOS Router Software With PPTP Enabled Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Version(s): 12.1 train, releases: T, E, EZ, YA, YD and YC; 12.2 train, all releases
Description:
Cisco reported that the PPTP implementation in certain Cisco IOS  software releases contains a vulnerability that allows a remote user to crash the router if PPTP is enabled on the router.
If a remote user sends a malformed or specially crafted PPTP packet to a Cisco Router running an affected version of IOS and having PPTP enabled, the router will crash after receiving a single packet.  The packet must be sent to the PPTP control port (port 1723).

The vendor notes that the IOS 11.x train does not support PPTP and is not affected.

This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco Bug ID CSCdt46181.
Impact': A remote user can crash the router by sending a single packet.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Vendor URL for the upgrade instructions.

Title: Cisco SN 5420 Storage Router Gives Special Administrative Access to Remote Users and Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
Cisco reports that two vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Cisco SN 5420 Storage Router.  One allows remote users to cause the router to reboot and the other allows remote users to obtain special administrative access to the router.
A remote user can cause the device to reboot by rapidly establishing multiple connections to TCP port 8023.          
A remote user can access a developer's shell account on the device by using rlogin (port 513) or connecting to port 8023 from the GigabitEthernet or management interface.  It is reported that no authentication is required.  The user's login and all commands executed by the user are not logged.

The vulnerabilities have been assigned Cisco Bug IDs CSCdu27529 and CSCdu27514.
Impact':
A remote user can prevent users from accessing storage.

A remote user (exploiting the developer's shell vulnerability) can execute debug commands, start and stop processes, and interfere with the normal process execution.
Solution: The vendor has provided a fixed version 1.1(4).  See the Vendor URL for information on obtaining the upgrade.

Title: Openwave's Mobile Access Gateway WAP Gateway Fails to Validate SSL Server Certificates in the Default Configuration
Description:
A security weakness was reported in the default configuration of Openwave's WAP gateway (Openwave Mobile Access Gateway) that causes the gateway to fail to verify the cryptographic validity of SSL server certificates.
When a remote mobile user connects to a secure web server via the WAP gateway, the gateway reportedly does not verify the server's certificate when the WAP gateway's default configuration is used.  This makes it difficult for the remote user to determine if the secure web server is the valid server.
Impact': When a remote mobile user connects to a secure web server via the WAP gateway, the user may communicate with an invalid secure server without knowledge that the server's certificate is invalid.
Solution: A configuration modification can be made to enable certificate validation.  The nature of the modification was not specified in the report.

Title: Cayman 3220-H ADSL Gateway Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Conducting Port Scans
Version(s): Cayman-DSL Model 3220-H router with GatorSurf version 5.6.1 (build R0)
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the Cayman 3220-H ADSL gateway that allows a remote user to crash the router by conducting a port scan on the router's IP address.
When using the nmap portscanner to scan the router's IP address, the router will reportedly crash a few minutes after the scan has been started.  This vulnerability can reportedly be triggered using both a TCP SynScan and a TCP Connect scan.
Impact': A remote user can crash the gateway.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (CIAC Issues Advisory L-106) Re: Cisco IOS Gives Remote Users Full Control of IOS Devices When HTTP Server Authentication with Local Authorization is Enabled
Description:
Cisco reported a vulnerability in their IOS device operating system that allows remote users to log in without requiring authentication under certain configurations and gives those users full control of the IOS device.
It is reported that it is possible, under certain circumstances, for a remote user to bypass authentication and execute any command on the device when HTTP server is enabled and local authorization is used.  All commands will be executed with the highest privilege (level 15).

Cisco notes that virtually all mainstream Cisco routers and switches running Cisco IOS are affected by this vulnerability.

A remote user can send a specially crafted URL to bypass authentication on a Cisco IOS device if the device is using a local database for authentication (i.e., usernames and passwords are defined on the device itself).  The vendor notes that the same URL will not be effective against every Cisco IOS software release and hardware combination, but that there are only 84 different combinations to try.

A URL in the following format can trigger the vulnerability:

http://<device_addres>/level/xx/exec/....

Where xx is a number between 16 and 99.

Cisco has assigned Cisco Bug ID CSCdt93862 to this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can log in and execute any command on the device using the highest privilege level (level 15).
Solution: The vendor is making upgraded IOS versions available (see the Source Message for a table that lists the various affected versions and the appropriate upgraded versions).  The vendor indicates that a workaround for this vulnerability is to disable HTTP server on the router or to use Terminal Access Controller Access Control System (TACACS+) or Radius for authentication.

Title: (Exploit Code is Released) Re: Cisco IOS Gives Remote Users Full Control of IOS Devices When HTTP Server Authentication with Local Authorization is Enabled
Description:
Cisco reported a vulnerability in their IOS device operating system that allows remote users to log in without requiring authentication under certain configurations and gives those users full control of the IOS device.
Demonstration exploit code is available at:

http://www.tamersahin.net/downloads/cisco_ios.zip
Impact': A remote user can log in and execute any command on the device using the highest privilege level (level 15).
Solution: The vendor is making upgraded IOS versions available (see the Source Message for a table that lists the various affected versions and the appropriate upgraded versions).  The vendor indicates that a workaround for this vulnerability is to disable HTTP server on the router or to use Terminal Access Controller Access Control System (TACACS+) or Radius for authentication.

Title: Symbol Access Point Wireless Gateway Discloses the Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP) Key and May Grant Wireless Access to Unauthorized Users
Description:
Internet Security Systems reported that Symbol's wireless Access Point gateway may disclose the device's Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP) key. This could allow a remote user to gain unauthorized access to the wireless LAN.
The product reportedly allows a remote user on the wired-side of the access point to obtain the WEP key by making a certain SNMP request:

1. IEEE 802.11b MIB: dot11WEPDefaultKeyValue in the dot11WEPDefaultKeysTable
2. Symbol MIB: ap128bWepKeyValue in the ap128bWEPKeyTable

With the WEP key, a remote user could obtain wireless access to the LAN.

The vulnerable product has apparently been provided to several Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) vendors.   A list of potentially affected vendors is available at:
http://www.symbol.com/products/wireless/wireless_alliances_and_partner.html

ISS recommends that all users of wireless gateways check their products for this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can obtain the WEP key from the wired-side interface and can use this key to obtain wireless access to the LAN.
Solution: The vendor has made a firmware update available.

Title: 3Com AirConnect Wireless Gateway Discloses the Wired Equivalent Privacy Key and May Grant Wireless Access to Unauthorized Users
Description:
Internet Security Systems issued a security advisory for 3Com's AirConnect wireless access gateway, warning that it may disclose the device's Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP) key.  This could allow a remote user to gain unauthorized access to the wireless LAN.
The product reportedly allows a remote user on the wired-side of the access point to obtain the WEP key by making a certain SNMP request:

1. IEEE 802.11b MIB: dot11WEPDefaultKeyValue in the dot11WEPDefaultKeysTable
2. Symbol MIB: ap128bWepKeyValue in the ap128bWEPKeyTable

With the WEP key, a remote user could obtain wireless access to the LAN.

The vulnerability reportedly resides in 802.11b Access Point technology provided by Symbol Technologies Inc. to 3Com and other Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) vendors.
Impact': A remote user can obtain the WEP key from the wired-side interface and can use this key to obtain wireless access to the LAN.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  3Com plans to release a firmware upgrade shortly.

Title: Netgear Wireless Access Point Fails to Restrict SNMP Access, Allowing Remote Users to Control the Device
Version(s): ME102, with Atmel firmware versions up to and including 1.3
Description:
Internet Security Systems reported a vulnerability in the NETGEAR ME102 Wireless Access Point. The device reportedly does not restrict access to the SNMP               management interface, allowing remote users to configure the device, view information about the configuration, and deny service to others using the device. 
The vulnerability reportedly resides in the authentication mechanism of the Atmel VNET-B Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) implementation (the Atmel device is provided via an Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) agreement with NETGEAR). 

The Atmel 802.11 VNET-B based Access Point supports the AT76C510 MIB that includes sensitive information like the ESSID, WEP key, and MAC addresses for the Access Point its clients. Access to this MIB is not restricted. The device reportedly does not require a community string to gain access to or control a wireless LAN.
Impact': A remote user can view and modify the SNMP variables and can gain access to the wireless LAN.
Solution: Upgrade to firmware version 1.4 when it becomes available. See the Vendor URL for upgrade information.

Title: Linksys Instant Network Wireless Access Point Does Not Restrict SNMP Access, Allowing Remote Users to Control the Device
Version(s): WAP 11; with Atmel firmware versions up to and including 1.3
Description:
Internet Security Systems reported a vulnerability in the Linksys WAP 11 wireless access point.  The device reportedly does not restrict access to the SNMP management interface, allowing remote users to configure the device, view information about the configuration, and deny service to others using the device.
The vulnerability reportedly resides in the authentication mechanism of the Atmel VNET-B Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) implementation (the Atmel device is provided via an Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) agreement with Linksys).  

The Atmel 802.11 VNET-B based Access Point supports the AT76C510 MIB that includes sensitive information like the ESSID, WEP key, and MAC addresses for the Access Point its clients.  Access to this MIB is not restricted.  The device reportedly does not require a community string to gain access to or control a wireless LAN.
Impact': A remote user can view and modify the SNMP variables and can gain access to the wireless LAN.
Solution: Upgrade to firmware version 1.4 when it becomes available.  See the Vendor URL for upgrade information.

Title: (CIAC Issues Bulletin L-097) Re: Cisco 6400 Access Concentrator Node Route Processor 2 (NRP2) Module Gives Remote Users Telnet Access Without Authentication Under Certain Conditions
Version(s): Cisco 6400 NRP2 modules running IOS earlier than 12.1(05)DC01
Description:
Cisco reported a vulnerability in their Cisco 6400 Access Concentrator Node Route Processor 2 (NRP2) module that allows remote users to access the device when no passwod has been set.
The Cisco 6400 Access Concentrator NRP2 module reportedly allows Telnet access when no password is set for the virtual terminals (vtys) on the NRP2, instead of denying remote access to the module until the password is set. Cisco states that this vulnerability affects the Gigabit Ethernet, ATM and Serial interface on the NRP2.

Cisco has assigned this vulnerability with bug ID CSCdt65960.
Impact': A remote user can gain access to secure systems if the initial virtual terminals have not had their password set.
Solution: The vendor has released a fixed version of IOS to correct this NRP2 vulnerability.  See the Vendor URL for upgrade instructions or for workaround instructions.

Title: Cisco 6400 Access Concentrator Node Route Processor 2 (NRP2) Module Gives Remote Users Telnet Access Without Authentication Under Certain Conditions
Version(s): Cisco 6400 NRP2 modules running IOS earlier than 12.1(05)DC01
Description:
Cisco reported a vulnerability in their Cisco 6400 Access Concentrator Node Route Processor 2 (NRP2) module that allows remote users to access the device when no passwod has been set.
The Cisco 6400 Access Concentrator NRP2 module reportedly allows Telnet access when no password is set for the virtual terminals (vtys) on the NRP2, instead of denying remote access to the module until the password is set. Cisco states that this vulnerability affects the Gigabit Ethernet, ATM and Serial interface on the NRP2.

Cisco has assigned this vulnerability with bug ID CSCdt65960.
Impact': A remote user can gain access to secure systems if the initial virtual terminals have not had their password set.
Solution: The vendor has released a fixed version of IOS to correct this NRP2 vulnerability.  See the Vendor URL for upgrade instructions or for workaround instructions.

Title: (CIAC Issues Corrected Bulletin L-90) Re: Cisco 11000 Series Content Service Switch Allows Remote Users to Gain Access to Web-Based Management Functions Without Authentication
Version(s): WebNS software earlier than 4.01B29s and earlier than 4.10B17s; CSS 11050, CSS 11150 and CSS 11800 hardware platforms
Description:
Cisco reported a security vulnerability in their Content Service Switch 11000 Series that allows remote users to gain access to web-based switch management functions without authentication.
Cisco announced that the CSS 11000 series switches do not enforce the correct restrictions for accessing the web management URL.

Cisco reports that when a remote user is authenticated via the web management URL, the remote user is then redirected to another URL.  If a remote user were to connected directly to the redirected URL, no authentication is required.  This lets unauthorized remote users access the switch's web management interface.

This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco bug ID CSCdu20931.
Impact': A remote user can gain access to the web management interface without authentication.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Vendor URL for directions on how to upgrade.  The vendor notes that users can disable the web management interface as a workaround.

Title: Cisco 11000 Series Content Service Switch Allows Remote Users to Gain Access to Web-Based Management Functions Without Authentication
Version(s): WebNS software earlier than 4.01B29s and earlier than 4.10B17s; CSS 11050, CSS 11150 and CSS 11800 hardware platforms
Description:
Cisco reported a security vulnerability in their Content Service Switch 11000 Series that allows remote users to gain access to web-based switch management functions without authentication.
Cisco announced that the CSS 11000 series switches do not enforce the correct restrictions for accessing the web management URL.

Cisco reports that when a remote user is authenticated via the web management URL, the remote user is then redirected to another URL.  If a remote user were to connected directly to the redirected URL, no authentication is required.  This lets unauthorized remote users access the switch's web management interface.

This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco bug ID CSCdu20931.
Impact': A remote user can gain access to the web management interface without authentication.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Vendor URL for directions on how to upgrade.  The vendor notes that users can disable the web management interface as a workaround.

Title: (CIAC Issues Bulletin L-088) Re: Cisco IOS Router Software May Reload Itself After Receiving a Vulnerability Scan
Version(s): IOS version 12.1(2)T and 12.1(3)T, and limited deployment releases based on those versions
Description:
Cisco reports a vulnerability in certain versions of their IOS router operating system that allows a remote user to cause the router's OS image to unexpectedly reload when the administrator uses certain commands (commands that should not cause a reload).
It is reported that there is a memory error in Cisco IOS  Software that will cause a reload to occur after receiveing a vulnerability scan when the administrator uses certain commands.

Cisco reports that attempts to establish a TCP connection to ports 3100-3999, 5100-5999, 7100-7999, and 10100-10999 will cause the router to unexpectedly reload the next time the administrator uses certain commands, such as "show running-config", "write memory", or any command that causes the configuration file to be accessed. 

Cisco notes that IOS does not run any services on those port numbers.

This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco Bug ID CSCds07326.
Impact': A remote user can cause the router to reload.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Vendor URL for directions on obtaining an upgrade.

Title: 3Com NETBuiler II Routers Allow Remote Users to Obtain Information from the Router Without Authorization
Description:
PlazaSite reported that 3Com's NETBuilder II routers contain an undocumented SNMP community string that allows remote users to obtain certain SNMP MIB data from the router.
It is reported that the NETBuilder II routes contain an undocumented read-only SNMP community called "ILMI".

A similar vulnerability has previously been reported in other routers, such as Cisco routers (see http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/ios-snmp-ilmi-vuln-pub.shtml for information about the previously reported Cisco vulnerability).

This was tested on CPU version 9.3 and serial card firmware is 2.5 (a rather old router).
Impact': A remote user can obtain certain SNMP MIB data from the router.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The report suggests disabling the snmp server feature as an interim measure.

Title: Cisco IOS Router Software May Reload Itself After Receiving a Vulnerability Scan
Version(s): IOS version 12.1(2)T and 12.1(3)T, and limited deployment releases based on those versions
Description:
Cisco reports a vulnerability in certain versions of their IOS router operating system that allows a remote user to cause the router's OS image to unexpectedly reload when the administrator uses certain commands (commands that should not cause a reload).
It is reported that there is a memory error in Cisco IOS  Software that will cause a reload to occur after receiveing a vulnerability scan when the administrator uses certain commands.

Cisco reports that attempts to establish a TCP connection to ports 3100-3999, 5100-5999, 7100-7999, and 10100-10999 will cause the router to unexpectedly reload the next time the administrator uses certain commands, such as "show running-config", "write memory", or any command that causes the configuration file to be accessed. 

Cisco notes that IOS does not run any services on those port numbers.

This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco Bug ID CSCds07326.
Impact': A remote user can cause the router to reload.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  See the Vendor URL for directions on obtaining an upgrade.

Title: (CIAC Issues Bulletin) Re: Cisco Reports Multiple Vulnerabilities in their 600 Series DSL routers (CBOS Operating System) That Allow Remote Users to Crash the Router or Possibly Gain Administrative Access to the Router
Description:
Cisco reports that there are multiple vulnerabilities in their Cisco 600 Series xDSL routers (running the Cisco Broadband Operating System).  The vulnerabilities allow remote users to cause the router to stop processing traffic or crash and may also provide additional opportunity for remote users to gain administrative access to the router.
Cisco reports the following flaws:

1) Predictability of TCP Initial Sequence Numbers. This reportedly only affects the security of TCP connections that originate or terminate on the router itself -- not the traffic process by the router.  This could allow a remote user to hijack an administrative session.  This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco bug ID CSCds16078.

2) If a remote user routes an ECHO REQUEST packet with the record route option via the router, the router may stop processing traffic and may not respond to the console.  This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco bug ID CSCds30150.

3)  Passwords (exec and enable) are stored in the cleartext in the non-volatile memory and in the configuration file.  This could allow a local user to obtain passwords.  This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco bug ID CSCdt04882.

4)  If a remote user sends multiple, large ECHO REPLY packets through a router, the router will enter the ROMMON mode and will stop processing any further traffic.  This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco bug ID CSCds74567.
Impact': Depending on the specific vulnerability, the following impact may apply.  A remote user could hijack a virtual console session with the router.  A remote user could cause the router to crash or stop processing traffic.  A local user could obtain passwords to the device.
Solution: The vendor has fixed these vulnerabilities in the following CBOS releases: 2.3.9, 2.4.1 and 2.4.2.  See the Vendor URL for information on obtaining the fixed versions.

Title: Cisco Reports Multiple Vulnerabilities in their 600 Series DSL routers (CBOS Operating System) That Allow Remote Users to Crash the Router or Possibly Gain Administrative Access to the Router
Description:

This could allow a remote user to hijack an administrative session.  This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco bug ID CSCds16078.

3)  Passwords (exec and enable) are stored in the cleartext in the non-volatile memory and in the configuration file.  This could allow a local user to obtain passwords.  This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco bug ID CSCdt04882.

Title: (CIAC Issues Bulletin) Re: Cisco Content Service Switch (Arrowpoint) Allows Authorized But Unprivileged Remote Users to Read and Write Any File on the System
Version(s): CSS 11050, CSS 11150 and CSS 11800 hardware platforms; WebNS software revisions earlier than 4.01B23s and earlier than 4.10B13s
Description:
Cisco announced a vulnerability in their Content Service Switch 11000 series switches that allows remote authorized but unprivileged users to to read and write any file on the system.
It is reported that the Cisco Content Service Switch (CSS) 11000 series switches do not enforce the correct restrictions for an authorized but non-privileged user when the remote user opens an FTP connection to the switch.  As a result, all users with valid accounts can use the FTP GET and PUT commands to read and write any file on the system, with no user-level restrictions enforced. 

This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco bug ID CSCdt64682.
Impact': An authorized but non-privileged remote user can gain access to files on the switch that the remote user is not authorized to access.
Solution: The vendor has released fixed software versions.  See the Vendor URL for the latest information on how to upgrade.

Title: Cisco Content Service Switch (Arrowpoint) Allows Authorized But Unprivileged Remote Users to Read and Write Any File on the System
Version(s): CSS 11050, CSS 11150 and CSS 11800 hardware platforms; WebNS software revisions earlier than 4.01B23s and earlier than 4.10B13s
Description:

It is reported that the Cisco Content Service Switch (CSS) 11000 series switches do not enforce the correct restrictions for an authorized but non-privileged user when the remote user opens an FTP connection to the switch.  As a result, all users with valid accounts can use the FTP GET and PUT commands to read and write any file on the system, with no user-level restrictions enforced. 

This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco bug ID CSCdt64682.
Impact': An authorized but non-privileged remote user can gain access to files on the switch that the remote user is not authorized to access.
Solution: The vendor has released fixed software versions.  See the Vendor URL for the latest information on how to upgrade.

Title: Allied Telesyn Router Lets Remote Users Access Port-Mapped Services Through the Router Even When Those Services Have Been Disabled
Description:
It is reported that there is a vulnerability in an Allied Telesyn AT Router that, in certain configurations, allows a remote user to traverse the router and access some "virtual server" port-mapped services even though they have been disabled.
The Allied Telesyn AT-AR220e combined DSL/Cable-Router provides a standard "Virtual Server" feature that uses portmappings.  The Virtual Server feature can be enabled/disabled and individual portmapping settings can be enabled/disabled.

It is reported that if an individual portmapping is set up but disabled and the virtual server feature is enabled, the router will ignore the disabled configuration of the individual portmapping.  As a result, a remote user can gain access through the router via the ostensibly disabled individual portmapping settings.
Impact': A remote user can obtain access to mapped services that appear to be disabled.
Solution: No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the advisory recommends that unused mappings should be deleted from the list-of-portmappings.

Title: (More Version Information) Re: 3Com OfficeConnect DSL Router Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in 3Com's OfficeConnect routers that allows remote users to cause the router to stop processing and reset itself.
A user reports that the 3Com OfficeConnect Remote 840 SDSL router is also affected.  This was tested with software version 1.0.7, firmware 4.2.  (The router model number is 3c840-US.)

When tested, the router reportedly did not automatically reset.

For details about the vulnerability, see the Message History.
Impact': A remote user can cause the router to crash.  The router will then automatically restart.
Solution: No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the advisory recommends placing filters on the router to restrict web-based administration to the local interface only.

Title: 3Com OfficeConnect DSL Router Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in 3Com's OfficeConnect routers that allows remote users to cause the router to stop processing and reset itself.
The router reportedly includes a password-protected HTTP server for web-based administration.  However, there is an image directory (/graphics) that does not require authentication.  If a particularly long string is supplied in a URL that references this directory, the router will reportedly crash.

An example demonstration exploit URL is:
http://[targetrouter]/graphics/sml3com%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%
s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s
%s%s%s%s%s%s%s

It is reported that this will cause the router to disconnect and then return online in a minute.

The vulnerability was tested with a 3Com OfficeConnect 812.
Impact': A remote user can cause the router to crash.  The router will then automatically restart.
Solution: No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the advisory recommends placing filters on the router to restrict web-based administration to the local interface only.

Title: Cisco IOS Routers Can Be Crashed By Invalid Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) Updates In Certain Configurations
Version(s): 11.CC and its derivatives, 11.2 and its derivaties, 11.3, 11.3T, 12.0, 12.0S and special branches taken out of 12.0.
Description:
Cisco issued an advisory warning that their IOS software contains a denial of service vulnerability that can be triggered by invalid attributes in a BGP update received from another router.  The vulnerability only exists in certain routing configurations.
Cisco reports that router configurations that include BGP4 Prefix Filtering with Inbound Route Maps are vulnerable.

Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) update messages contain Network Layer Reachability Information (NLRI) and attributes that describe the appropriate network path to the destination.  Each path attribute is composed of a type, length, and value (TLV) object.  If a BGP update message that contains an unrecognized transitive attribute is received, it can cause failures in Cisco IOS routers.

Cisco reports that this vulnerability is due to memory corruption.

Cisco devices that may be running with affected Cisco IOS software releases include:

Cisco routers in the AGS/MGS/CGS/AGS+, IGS, RSM, 800, ubr900, 1000, 1400, 1500, 1600, 1700, 2500, 2600, 3000, 3600, 3800, 4000, 4500, 4700, AS5200, AS5300, AS5800, 6400, 7000, 7200, ubr7200, 7500, and 12000 series.

This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco bug ID CSCdt79947.

The following versions of Cisco IOS are *not* vulnerable:

Software based on 12.1, 12.0(5)T, 12.2, 12.0ST, and 12.1(E).

Also, non-IOS products are not vulnerable.
Impact': The vulnerability can be triggered repeatedly if a router sends a BGP update with an unrecognized attribute, resulting in potentially widespread network outages.  The routers may crash upon receipt of the unrecognized transitive attribute, or the routers may crash later when an attempt to clear the unrecognized transitive attribute is made.
Solution: Cisco has released a fix.  Cisco urges affected customers to upgrade.  See the Source Message or the Vendor URL for upgrade information.

Title: Cisco Catalyst Switch Can Be Crashed By Remote Users in Certain Configurations
Version(s): Tested on Software Version 12.0(5.2)XU on WS-C2924C-XL-EN switch
Description:
It is reported that there is a vulnerability in Cisco's Catalyst switch that allows a remote user to cause the switch to crash if SNMP is disabled on the switch.
By sending an empty UDP packet to port 161 (the SNMP port) on the Cisco Catalyst 2900XL when SNMP is disabled, a remote user can cause the switch to crash.  It is not clear if other switch models are vulnerable.

The crash reportedly only occurs when the switch is booted with SNMP disabled.

Code for a simple empty UDP packet generator is included in the Source Message (encoded file).
Impact': A remote user can cause the Catalyst switch to crash by sending an empty UDP packet to the SNMP port (if the switch is confiugred with SNMP *disabled*).
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  However, the author of the advisory suggests that users can either enable SNMP or can enable SNMP and then disable SNMP to avoid this problem

Title: (A User Describes An Exploit Scenario) Re: Alcatel's Speed Touch ADSL Modems Can Give Remote Users Complete Contol of the Device
Description:
It is reported that Alcatel's Speed Touch ADSL-Ethernet bridge devices contain multiple vulnerabilities that allow remote users to take control of the device, change its configuration, upload new firmware, and disrupt communications.  This was discovered by researchers associated with the San Diego Supercomputer Center at the University of California, San Diego.
The device ships with no passwords as a default setting. Once the password is set, it can be retrieved or changed by any remote user using TFTP. Apparently, there is also a cryptographic challenge-response backdoor access method that bypasses any user passwords.  Testing performed in preparing this report was done in LLC/SNAP bridge mode. Routing mode was not tested. 

A user describes an exploit scenario for the ALCATEL Speed Touch Pro that allows a remote user to gain "full priv" access to the router and, from there, launch several attack against the internal LAN.  See the source message for details.
Impact':
These vulnerabilities reported allow the following actions to be performed by remote users:

1) changing the device's configuration such that the device can no longer be accessed;

2) disabling the device, either temporarily or permanently (requiring return of the device to the manufacturer); and

3) installation of malicious code, such as a network sniffer   to gather local LAN traffic (that is not being bridged) and making the box more easily/covertly remotely accessible.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Confirms) Re: Cisco Broadband Operating System for ADSL Routers May Disclose Some Configuration Data to Unauthorized Users in Certain Cases
Description:
A bug has been reported in the Cisco Broadband Operating System (CBOS) on the Cisco 677 ADSL router that may allow remote users to access some device status information in certain cases.
A user reports that while performing the administrative function "sh nat" via telnet where the display listing was very long, it was possible to access some of the data by connecting via telnet from a different IP host. The "sh nat" (show nat) command is used to display the NAT Status and Network Side for all Interfaces. The C677 reportedly switched output to that new connection before prompting the user for a password. The listing would continue in whatever telnet window had the last keypress.

Cisco confirms the vulnerability and is working on a fix.  Cisco indicates that, to the best of their knowledge, this vulnerability can be only be triggered by using the "sh nat" command. Apparently, this cannot be reproduced by any other command (e.g, the "sh conf" is not vulnerable).

In addition, Cisco indicates that you can only see the output from the first session.  The second session is not an authenticated session and, therefore, does not allow any commands to be executed (untill you actually log in). Also, only the output of a single command is displayed.  All subsequent commands other than "sh nat" are displayed in the proper session.
Impact': A remote user could connect to the device's telnet port and, in some cases, obtain data that was being displayed by a valid administrator on another telnet session.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor is working on a fix.

Title: Cisco Broadband Operating System for ADSL Routers May Disclose Some Configuration Data to Unauthorized Users in Certain Cases
Description:

The "sh nat" (show nat) command is used to display the NAT Status and Network Side for all Interfaces. 

The C677 reportedly switched output to that new connection before prompting the user for a password.  The listing would continue in whatever telnet window had the last keypress.

Title: (CIAC Issues Bulletin) Re: Cisco Catalyst Switch May Allow a Denial of Service Condition
Description:
Cisco released a security advisory for their Catalyst 5000 Series switch warning of a vulnerability that allows certain Ethernet packets to be forwarded rather than blocked, creating a potential denial of service condition.
Cisco reports that when an 802.1x frame is received by an affected Catalyst 5000 series switch on a STP blocked port it is forwarded in that VLAN instead of being dropped. This apparently causes a network storm in that part of the network that is made up of the affected Catalyst 5000 series switches. 

This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco bug id CSCdt62732.

Affected products include the Catalyst models 5000, 5002, 5500, 5505, 5509, 2901, 2902 and 2926 switches.  See the vendor bulletin for affected version numbers.  Catalyst 5000 series switches based on EARL 2 or later hardware revisions are not affected by this vulnerability.
Impact': A local user with access to the local segment can generate a certain Ethernet packet that will cause a network storm in that part of the network, resulting in denial of service.
Solution: Cisco has released a fix. See the vendor URL.  For the contents of the CIAC bulletin number L-072, see the source message.
