Title: Lightwave Communications ConsoleServer 2000 Discloses System Information to Unauthenticated Remote Users
Description:
The Lightwave ConsoleServer 3200 contains a reported vulnerability that provides system information to unauthenticated users prior to login.  The system also does not provide any failed login timeouts and does not drop the TCP connection of the attempted login session when a failed login occurs.
When a remote user connects to the ConsoleServer 3200 via the unit's System Administrator interface (TCP port 5000), the built-in command line interface provides the following information before the administrator is required to login: Expansion cards are in the unit, Users that are currently logged into the unit, serial ports that have been configured, power supply status, and Ethernet interface configuration (e.g., MAC address, gateway, netmask).

While incorrect administrator login attempts are limited to three, it appears that those events are not logged.
Impact': A remote user can obtain information about the system (such as user names and various configuration information) that can be used to faciliate an attack.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (CERT Issues Advisory) Re: Alcatel's Speed Touch ADSL Modems Can Give Remote Users Complete Contol of the Device
Description:
It is reported that Alcatel's Speed Touch ADSL-Ethernet bridge devices contain multiple vulnerabilities that allow remote users to take control of the device, change its configuration, upload new firmware, and disrupt communications.  This was discovered by researchers associated with the San Diego Supercomputer Center at the University of California, San Diego.
CERT has issued Advisory CA-2001-08 regarding these vulnerabilities.  The following systems are affected:  Alcatel Speed Touch Home ADSL Modem, and Alcatel 1000 ADSL Network Termination Device.

For details on the vulnerabilities, please see:

http://security.sdsc.edu/self-help/alcatel/
Impact':
These vulnerabilities reported allow the following actions to be performed by remote users:

1) changing the device's configuration such that the device can no longer be accessed;

2) disabling the device, either temporarily or permanently (requiring return of the device to the manufacturer); and

3) installation of malicious code, such as a network sniffer   to gather local LAN traffic (that is not being bridged) and making the box more easily/covertly remotely accessible.
Solution: The CERT Advisory provides information on how to mitigate the risk posed by these vulnerabilities.  See the source message or the CERT advisory: http://www.cert.org/advisories/CA-2001-08.html

Title: Alcatel's Speed Touch ADSL Modems Can Give Remote Users Complete Contol of the Device
Description:
It is reported that Alcatel's Speed Touch ADSL-Ethernet bridge devices contain multiple vulnerabilities that allow remote users to take control of the device, change its configuration, upload new firmware, and disrupt communications.  This was discovered by researchers associated with the San Diego Supercomputer Center at the University of California, San Diego.
The device ships with no passwords as a default setting.  Once the password is set, it can be retrieved or changed by any remote user using TFTP.  Apparently, there is also a cryptographic challenge-response backdoor access method that bypasses any user passwords.  Details are provided in the source message.

Testing performed in preparing this report was done in LLC/SNAP bridge mode.  Routing mode was not tested.
Impact':

1) changing the device's configuration such that the device can no longer be accessed;

3) installation of malicious code, such as a network sniffer   to gather local LAN traffic (that is not being bridged) and making the box more easily/covertly remotely accessible.

Title: (Vendor Makes Recommendations) Re: BinTec X4000 Router Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Version(s): 5.1.6 Patch 10 of the bootimage and logicware 1.05; possibly others
Description:
It was reported that the BinTec X4000 router will crash when a remote user conducts a simple TCP SYN portscan.
When a remote user conducts a TCP SYN portscan (for example, using the nmap scanning tool with the command "nmap -sS"), the BinTec X4000 will lock up. Once this has occurred, the device requires a cold reboot (power cycle) to return to normal operation. 

The vendor makes recommendations for the affected platforms (BinTec X1000, BinTec X1200, BinTec X4000) -- see the "solution" section.

The vendor notes that systems with the following properties are *NOT* affected: VPN license activated, or port 1723/tcp blocked for all interfaces.
Impact': A remote user can scan the ports on the router, causing it to crash.
Solution:
The vendor will fix this vulnerability in the next release.  In the meantime, the vendor recommends the following:

"that you block all unused ports and update to the latest system software.  In any case, port 1723/tcp should be closed for all interfaces on systems without VPN license.  You can block the ports either by using the access lists of the router or by activating NAT."

Title: (Clarification) Re: BinTec X4000 Router Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Version(s): 5.1.6 Patch 10 of the bootimage and logicware 1.05; possibly others
Description:
It was reported that the BinTec X4000 router will crash when a remote user conducts a simple TCP SYN portscan.
It was reported that sending a SYN flagged TCP packet to port 1723 (PPTP) will cause the router to crash.  The PPTP daemon is the source of the vulnerability.  It is intended to be activated only when the appropriate software license key is entered, but this process is not working properly.  As a result, when the ostensibly deactivated PPTP daemon receives a TCP SYN packet, the process will consum all CPU resources.

It is reported that routers that are configured with the additional VPN software license are not vulnerable and routers that filter tcp port 1723 are not vulnerable.
Impact': A remote user can scan the ports on the router, causing it to crash.
Solution: Filter out tcp port 1723.  The vendor will likely release a fix.

Title: (CIAC Issues Bulletin) Re: Cisco's Content Services Switch (Arrowpoint) Allows Administrators to Escalate Privileges and Make Unauthorized Configuration Changes
Version(s): prior to 4.01B19s; CSS 11050, CSS 11150, and CSS 11800 hardware platforms
Description:
Cisco released an advisory for their Cisco Content Services Switch (also known as Arrowpoint) regarding a vulnerability that can allow authorized administrators to escalate their administrative privileges and make unauthorized configuration changes.
A non-privileged but valid administrative user can issue a certain series of keystrokes to enter the debug mode and, from that mode, can then gain super-user administrative access.
Impact': This vulnerability can allow a non-privileged administrative user to gain super-user access and gain unauthorized access to important files (such as the configuration files) and to directory structure information.
Solution: An upgraded version is available.  Upgrade to revision 4.01B19s for all affected platforms. This vulnerability is assigned Cisco bug ID CSCdt32570.

Title: BinTec X4000 Router Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Version(s): 5.1.6 Patch 10 of the bootimage and logicware 1.05; possibly others
Description:
It was reported that the BinTec X4000 router will crash when a remote user conducts a simple TCP SYN portscan.
When a remote user conducts a TCP SYN portscan (for example, using the nmap scanning tool with the command "nmap -sS"), the BinTec X4000 will lock up.  Once this has occurred, the device requires a cold reboot (power cycle) to return to normal operation.

The vendor has reportedly been contacted.
Impact': A remote user can scan the ports on the router, causing it to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Cisco's Content Services Switch (Arrowpoint) Allows Administrators to Escalate Privileges and Make Unauthorized Configuration Changes
Version(s): prior to 4.01B19s; CSS 11050, CSS 11150, and CSS 11800 hardware platforms
Description:
Cisco released an advisory for their Cisco Content Services Switch (also known as Arrowpoint) regarding a vulnerability that can allow authorized administrators to escalate their administrative privileges and make unauthorized configuration changes.
A non-privileged but valid administrative user can issue a certain series of keystrokes to enter the debug mode and, from that mode, can then gain super-user administrative access.
Impact': This vulnerability can allow a non-privileged administrative user to gain super-user access and gain unauthorized access to important files (such as the configuration files) and to directory structure information.
Solution: An upgraded version is available.  Upgrade to revision 4.01B19s for all affected platforms. This vulnerability is assigned Cisco bug ID CSCdt32570.

Title: Agere's ORiNOCO RG-1000 Broadcasts the Default Encryption Key Which Gives Remote Users Access to Encrypted Wireless Networks
Description:
It was announced that Agere's ORiNOCO RG-1000 residential wireless gateway ships discloses the default WEP key if it has not been changed by the user, allowing remote users to gain access to the network.
The default WEP key is set to the default network name, which is broadcase in the clear in several 802.11 management frames.  If the default key has not been changed, a remote user can sniff the network and determine the default WEP key (the last five digits of the network name).

The default network name was observed by the author of the source message to be the last six nibbles of the MAC address converted into ASCII.
Impact': If the default WEP key has not been changed, a remote user can sniff the network and determine the default WEP key.
Solution: Vendor documentation strongly recommends changing the default key.

Title: Agere's ORiNOCO Wireless LAN Cards Give Any User Access to Closed Networks
Version(s): Most access points based on Orinoco wireless cards.
Description:
A vulnerability was announced in Agere's ORiNOCO wireless LAN products that allow any user to join a "closed" network.  [Agere is formely Lucent's Microelectronics Group.]
The ORiNOCO products reportedly use a proprietary access control mechanism called "Closed Network" that requires clients to have knowledge of the network name (SSID) in order to join a closed network.  The SSID acts as a shared secret to control access.  However, several 802.11 management messages contain the network name and are broadcast without encryption by LAN access points and clients.  A remote user can sniff the wireless network communications to obtain the network name and can then join the network.

More information is provided in:

"Your 802.11 Wireless Network has No Clothes."
http://www.cs.umd.edu/~waa/wireless.pdf
Impact': An attacker can determine the network name (SSID) and join a closed network, gaining immediate unrestricted access.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  If WEP (wireless encapsulation protocol) is used, this vulnerability is not directly exploitable.

Title: Crosscomm/Olicom Routers Have an Undocumented SNMP Access Password That Allows Unauthorized Viewing Modification of Router Settings
Description:
Crosscomm/Olicom routers reportedly have a undocumented SNMP community string ILMI that has both read and write permissions, allowing unauthorized users to remotely view and change settings on the router.
The author of the source message did not verify the entire MIB tree, but notes that you can, for example, set system.sysContact.0. This was verified on an XLT-F router with software 'XL 80 IM Version 5.5 Build Level 2'.

Intel acquired Crosscomm, which had earlier acquired Olicom.  The support status of these products is unknown.
Impact': An unauthorized remote user can view and change settings on the router via the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) Management Information Base (MIB).
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Cisco's Aironet Wireless Bridge Allows Display and Modification Via Web Even When the Web Interface Is Disabled
Description:
Cisco announced a vulnerability in their Aironet series wireless bridge products that allow an attacker to view and modify the bridge's configuration via the web interface even when web access is disabled in the configuration.
This vulnerability was assigned Cisco bug ID CSCdt52783.

The following models are affected: Aironet AP4500, Aironet AP4800, Aironet BR100, Aironet BR500, and Aironet AIR-BR340.
Impact': An attacker with connectivity to the bridge via wireless or wired Ethernet can view and modify the bridge's configuration.
Solution: Cisco has issued firmware release 8.55 that corrects the problem.
